senses.definition: used when you are referring to things that remind you of a particular person, thing or time
examples: short skirts and long boots—shades of the 1960s

senses.definition: the dark shape that somebody/something’s form makes on a surface, for example on the ground, when they are between the light and the surface
examples: The children were having fun, chasing each other's shadows.
As the curtains moved in the breeze, the shadows on the floor seemed to dance.
The ship's sail cast a shadow on the water.
The shadows lengthened as the sun went down.
The man's face is hidden in a deep shadow cast by his umbrella.
They saw the shadow of a man pass by.
(figurative) He didn't want to cast a shadow on (= spoil) their happiness.
Let’s sit in the shade for a while.
As the sun went down we cast long shadows on the lawn.
Her face was in deep shadow.
A dark shadow loomed over her.
Deep shadows lay across the small clearing where they sat.
The candles on the table threw huge flickering shadows against the wall.
The shadows of the clouds passed over us.
Use a desk light to produce a strong shadow.
As he stood still I traced the outline of his shadow on the wall.

senses.definition: darkness in a place or on something, especially so that you cannot easily see who or what is there
examples: in the shadows I thought I saw a figure standing in the shadows.
in shadow His face was deep in shadow, turned away from her.
A man in black emerged from the shadows.
It had grown dark, and the shadows could be hiding anything.
It's a spooky story about the monsters that lurk in the shadows.
She shrank back into the shadows as the footsteps approached.
‘I'm right here,’ I said, stepping out of the shadows.
Let’s sit in the shade for a while.
As the sun went down we cast long shadows on the lawn.
Her face was in deep shadow.
I could just make out a figure in the shadows.
Suddenly a huge figure loomed up out of the shadows.
The house lay in dark shadow.
The storm clouds threw the mountain peaks into dense shadow.
She lay on the bed in a pool of shadow.

senses.definition: a very small amount of something
examples: A shadow of a smile touched his mouth.
She knew beyond a shadow of a doubt (= with no doubt at all) that he was lying.

senses.definition: the strong (often bad) influence of somebody/something
examples: The new leader wants to escape from the shadow of his predecessor.
Bergman casts a long shadow over world cinema.
under the shadow of somebody/something These people have been living for years under the shadow of fear.

senses.definition: dark areas under somebody’s eyes, because they are tired, etc.
examples: She looked pale, with deep shadows under her eyes.

senses.definition: a person or an animal that follows somebody else all the time
a weaker or worse version of somebody/something
examples: So far this season the player has been a shadow of himself.
The result is a product that is a shadow of the real thing.

senses.definition: a thing that is not real or possible to obtain
examples: You can't spend all your life chasing shadows.

senses.definition: to be very easily frightened; to be very nervous
to not have the strength, influence, etc. that you used to have
examples: When his career ended, he became a shadow of his former self.

senses.definition: very close to
examples: The new market is in the shadow of the City Hall.

senses.definition: when you say that somebody is in/under the shadow of another person, you mean that they do not receive as much attention as that person
examples: A younger son often lives in the shadow of his elder brother.

senses.definition: an act of shaking somebody/something
examples: She gave him a shake to wake him.
Give the bottle a good shake before opening.
shake of something He dismissed the idea with a firm shake of his head (= turning it from side to side to mean ‘no’).
He gave himself a mental shake and got down to work.
a rueful shake of the head

senses.definition: a physical condition in which you cannot stop your body from shaking because of fear, illness, or because you have drunk too much alcohol
examples: I always get the shakes before exams.

senses.definition: a drink made of milk, and sometimes ice cream, with the added taste of fruit or chocolate, which is mixed or shaken until it is full of bubbles
examples: a strawberry shake

senses.definition: to be not very good, efficient, suitable, etc.
(to give somebody/get) fair treatment that gives you the same chance as somebody else
examples: Are minority students getting a fair shake at college?
We need a government that cares about equity and a fair go for all.

senses.definition: very soon
examples: We’ll be there in a couple of shakes.

senses.definition: to move or make somebody/something move with short quick movements from side to side or up and down
examples: The whole house shakes when a train goes past.
shake somebody/something Shake the bottle well before use.
The explosion shook windows miles from the site.
shake somebody/something by something She shook him by the shoulders.
shake somebody/something + adj. He knelt and gently shook her awake.
She shook her hair loose.
The ground began to shake.
He shook the blankets vigorously to get rid of the dust.
Shake the pan gently to settle the contents.

senses.definition: to move something in a particular direction by shaking
examples: She bent down to shake a pebble out of her shoe.
His father used to come home and shake the dust off his work clothes.
He stood up, shaking sand everywhere.

senses.definition: to take somebody’s hand and move it up and down as a way of saying hello or to show that you agree about something
examples: shake hands Do people in Italy shake hands when they meet?
shake hands with somebody She refused to shake hands with him.
shake somebody’s hand He stepped forward and shook my hand.
shake somebody by the hand Our host shook each of us warmly by the hand.
shake hands on something They shook hands on the deal (= to show that they had reached an agreement).
shake on something They shook on the deal (= shook hands to show the deal was agreed).
Let's shake on it.
The captains shook hands before the game commenced.
If I met him I'd shake him by the hand and congratulate him.

senses.definition: to turn your head from side to side as a way of saying ‘no’ or to show that you are sad, feel doubt, etc.
examples: ‘Drink?’ he offered. She shook her head.
The old man watched them walk off into the night, shaking his head sadly.
She shook her head in disbelief.
He shook his head at the thought.

senses.definition: to show that you are angry with somebody; to threaten somebody by shaking your fist (= closed hand)
examples: The man shook his fist at the court after he was sentenced.

senses.definition: to make short quick movements that you cannot control, for example because you are cold or afraid
examples: Her hands had started to shake.
shake with something He was shaking with fear.
He saw his mother turn away, her shoulders shaking with laughter.
His whole body shook with rage.
I was shaking like a leaf.
He was almost shaking with the intensity of what he was saying.
He was crying and shaking all over.
I found myself shaking uncontrollably with cold.
I just couldn't stop shaking.
I was numb with dread. I was literally shaking.
Roxy was practically shaking with anger.
Natalie fairly shook with laughter.
She got up, her legs shaking as well as her hands.

senses.definition: to sound unsteady, usually because you are nervous, upset or angry
examples: ‘Who are you?’ he asked, his voice shaking.
Her voice shook with emotion.

senses.definition: to shock or upset somebody very much
examples: shake somebody He was badly shaken by the news of her death.
shake somebody up The accident really shook her up.
Shaken up by the early goal against them, the team began to fight back.

senses.definition: to make a belief or an idea less certain
examples: The incident had shaken her faith in him.
This announcement is bound to shake the confidence of the industry.

senses.definition: to get rid of something
examples: shake something off I can't seem to shake off this cold.
She has finally managed to shake off her old wrist injury.
shake something He couldn't shake the feeling that there was something wrong.
She never seemed to completely shake off the dumb blonde image.

senses.definition: to cause people to question their basic beliefs about something
examples: This issue has shaken the foundations of French politics.
an event which rocked the foundations of British politics
The scandal rocked the legal establishment to its foundations.

senses.definition: to be very frightened or nervous
used to tell somebody to start to do something or to hurry
used with I and we for talking about or predicting the future
examples: This time next week I shall be in Scotland.
We shan't be gone long.
I said that I should be pleased to help.

senses.definition: used in questions with I and we for making offers or suggestions or asking advice
examples: Shall I send you the book?
What shall we do this weekend?
Let's look at it again, shall we?
I’ll (= I will) be late
‘You’ll (= you will) apologize immediately.’
‘No I won’t!’
What shall I wear to the party?
Shall we order some coffee?
I’ll drive, shall I?
Would you like me to help you with that?
Can I give you a hand?
Can I help you with that?
Shall I carry that for you?
Would it help if I spoke to Julie before you call her?
Let me take your bag.
If there's anything I can do (to help), let me know.
That's very kind of you. Thank you.
Thank you. It's very nice of you to offer.
It's all right, thank you. I can manage.
Thanks. That would be very helpful.

senses.definition: used to show that you are determined, or to give an order or instruction
examples: He is determined that you shall succeed.
Candidates shall remain in their seats until all the papers have been collected.
He can speak three languages.
She will try and visit tomorrow.
You must find a job.
You ought to stop smoking.
I used to smoke but I gave up two years ago.
Can I invite Mary?
Should I have invited Mary?

senses.definition: not having much distance between the top or surface and the bottom
examples: a shallow dish/pan/bowl
a shallow sea/lake/pool/pond
They were playing in the shallow end (= of the swimming pool).
These fish are found in shallow waters around the coast.
The body was found in a shallow grave.
Most earthquakes occur at much shallower depths.
shallow roots (= that grow near the surface of the ground)
Don't worry, the water's very shallow.
Follow the south shore, crossing the river where it is shallow enough.

senses.definition: not showing serious thought, feelings, etc. about something
examples: This shows how shallow their commitment to the environment really is.
Tony seemed very shallow and immature.

senses.definition: shallow breathing involves taking in only a small amount of air each time
used to say that something is a cause for feeling sad or disappointed
examples: She's retiring because of ill health, which is a great shame.
What happened was a real shame.
shame (that)… It's a shame that she wasn't here to see it.
Shame they didn't think of that earlier.
It’s a shame (that) you didn’t say something sooner.
What a shame they couldn't come.
shame about somebody/something It's a shame about Tim, isn't it?
shame about somebody/something doing something It's a terrible shame about Stuart losing his job, isn't it?
shame to do something It's a shame to see her wasting her talent like this.
shame for somebody/something to do something It'd be a shame for us to give up now.
It would be a crying shame (= a great shame) not to take them up on the offer.
It seems such a shame to throw perfectly good food away.
Shame they couldn't make it.
It is a national shame that our prisons serve as mental institutions.
It would be a shame for all the work that has been done to be wasted.

senses.definition: the feelings of being sad, embarrassed or guilty that you have when you know that something you have done is wrong or stupid
examples: with shame His face burned with shame.
They should blush with shame.
in shame She hung her head in shame.
shame of something The king preferred death to the shame of defeat.
shame of doing something It took me a while to get over the shame of not doing something to help him.
shame of somebody/something doing something He could not live with the shame of other people knowing the truth.
shame at something I felt a twinge of shame at the thought.
shame at doing something She admitted her shame at having a parent in prison.
shame for doing something He was filled with shame for giving in to his anger.
shame for something She expressed her shame for her role in the whole unfortunate business.
I would die of shame if she ever found out.
To my shame (= I feel shame that) I refused to listen to her side of the story.
Do you feel no shame for what you've done?
He had cried noisily and without shame at the news of Esther's death.
Her pregnancy was no cause for shame.
She felt a flush of shame at what she'd done.
She wept from the shame of having let everyone down.
This is the secret shame I have carried around for decades.

senses.definition: the ability to feel shame at something you have done
examples: Have you no shame?
without shame That child is completely without shame!
She has no sense of shame.

senses.definition: the loss of respect that is caused when you do something wrong or stupid
examples: There is no shame in wanting to be successful.
(formal) She felt that her failure would bring shame on her family.
He risked public shame and possible imprisonment.

senses.definition: to be much better than somebody/something
examples: Their presentation put ours to shame.
Her energy and enthusiasm puts the rest of us to shame (= makes us feel embarrassed and guilty that we are not the same).

senses.definition: used to say that somebody should feel ashamed for something they have said or done
examples: Shame on you for doubting me!

senses.definition: the form of the outer edges or surfaces of something; an example of something that has a particular form
examples: a rectangular/spherical/cylindrical shape
geometric shapes
fantastic creatures that can change shape and be either visible or invisible
You can recognize the fish by the shape of their fins.
They have completely different body shapes.
This old T-shirt has completely lost its shape.
in shape The island was originally circular in shape.
Several rooms are irregular in shape.
Candles come in all shapes and sizes.
Glass is blown or moulded into many shapes.
in the shape of something The pool was in the shape of a heart.
(figurative) The government provides money in the shape of (= consisting of) grants and student loans.
Squares, circles and triangles are types of shape.
First draw the rough shape of your chosen animal.
Fold the paper to make the shape of a cone.
I recognized the distinctive shape of a 747.
Ordinary things assumed different shapes in the mist.
She drew inspiration from organic shapes in the surrounding landscape.
The road forms an L shape.
Opt for a hairstyle to suit your face shape.
You can't change your natural body shape.
The bruise was a sort of mushroom shape.
The desk was an awkward shape and wouldn't fit through the door.

senses.definition: a person or thing that is difficult to see clearly
examples: Ghostly shapes moved around in the dark.
I could just make out a dark shape in the distance.
An enormous shape loomed up out of the mist directly in front of me.

senses.definition: the physical condition of somebody/something
examples: in … shape What sort of shape was the car in after the accident?
He's in good shape for someone who had surgery six months ago.
The ship was in bad shape as a result of damage sustained in the collision.
He’s not in any shape (= not well enough) to be working.
After the night before, he was in rough shape.
My mother is in better physical shape than I am.
She likes to stay in shape.
(figurative) The economy is still in pretty good shape.
(figurative) The company is in good financial shape.

senses.definition: the particular qualities or characteristics of something
examples: Will new technology change the shape of broadcasting?
Prices vary according to the size and shape of each project.
He did much to determine the shape of Asia's political map.

senses.definition: to become angry, anxious or upset
examples: Don't get bent out of shape about it. It was just a mistake!

senses.definition: to take exercise, eat healthy food, etc. in order to become physically fit
examples: I’m trying to get into shape before summer.
I need to get back into shape after the Christmas holiday.

senses.definition: to train somebody so that they do a particular job, task, etc. well
examples: It took him just two weeks to knock the new recruits into shape.

senses.definition: to make something more acceptable, organized or successful
examples: I've got all the information together but it still needs knocking into shape.
It shouldn’t take long to get the company back into shape.

senses.definition: to express or explain a particular idea, plan, etc.
examples: Marie tried to find the right words to give shape to the confusion in her head.

senses.definition: of any type
examples: I don't approve of violence in any shape or form.
I can't stand insects in any shape or form.
I do not condone bullying in any way, shape or form.

senses.definition: (to get/stay) in good physical condition
examples: You don't have to spend a fortune on gym membership to get in shape.
I like to stay in shape.

senses.definition: not having the normal shape
examples: The wheel had been twisted out of shape.
The bicycle had been battered out of shape.

senses.definition: not in good physical condition
examples: I didn’t realize how out of shape I was!

senses.definition: the way things are likely to develop in the future
examples: Are solar-powered cars the shape of things to come?
This new system could be the shape of things to come.

senses.definition: to develop and become more complete or organized
examples: The garden is beginning to take shape.
A new song began to take shape in her mind.

senses.definition: to dance
examples: She spent the whole evening throwing shapes on the dance floor.

senses.definition: to behave in a way that makes you seem to threaten somebody, especially by standing as though you are ready to fight, without actually becoming violent
examples: I was worried he might get violent but he was just throwing shapes.
(figurative) The two main investors threw some shapes during the debate.

senses.definition: to make something into a particular shape
examples: shape A into B Shape the dough into a ball.
The man was busy shaping mud into bricks.
shape something This tool is used for shaping wood.
They use traditional methods to shape the stone.
tools for cutting and shaping metal

senses.definition: to have an important influence on the way that somebody/something develops
examples: You are helping to shape the future of this country.
She had a leading role in shaping party policy.
the historical circumstances that shaped their lives.
His ideas had been shaped by his experiences during the war.
He was responsible for shaping my career.
Memory can be profoundly shaped by subsequent experience.
Money played a major role in shaping his decision.
The fictional Capone has continued to shape America's vision of the 1920s.
The media had great influence in shaping public opinion.
Work was an important factor in shaping their children's attitudes.
Religion had long been losing its power to shape and control behaviour.

senses.definition: to prepare to do something, especially hit or kick something
examples: She was shaping to hit her second shot.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody that if they do not improve, work harder, etc. they will have to leave their job, position, etc.
examples: He finally faced up to his drug problem when his band told him to shape up or ship out.

senses.definition: one part of something that is divided between two or more people
examples: share of something Next year we hope to have a greater share of the market.
The charity was supposed to have been given a share of the profits.
The party won its biggest share of the vote since 1992.
The new TV channel has continued to increase its share of advertising revenue.
The three hospitals will each receive an equal share of the money raised.
Why should he be entitled to a larger share of the royalties?
How much was your share of the winnings?
share in something I have a 50 per cent share in the business.
If you die before your husband, your share in the property may go directly to your children.
(British English) I'm looking for a flat share (= a flat that is shared by two or more people who are not related).
She may be entitled to a share of his future earnings.
The region receives a higher share of tax revenue than it raises.
The wife owns an 80% share of their second home.
I'm hoping for a share in the profits.
She won a share of the spoils at the last competition.
The government devotes a disproportionate share of the budget to military expenditure.

senses.definition: the part that somebody has in a particular activity that involves several people
examples: We all did our share.
share of something Everyone must accept their share of the blame.
Churchill bore a huge share of the responsibility for this failure.
We must all do our share of the work.

senses.definition: an amount of something that is thought to be normal or acceptable for one person or thing
examples: He always eats more than his share.
share of something I've had my share of luck in the past.
I've done my share of worrying for one day!
The industry has had its share of problems this year.
a branch of literature which has yet to receive its full share of attention
It is right to pay your full share of tax.
She has seen her share of suffering.
He had done his share of partying in college.
Everyone wants to claim their share of fame and fortune.

senses.definition: the action of sending on a message on social media for other people to see
examples: The campaign has already received 180 000 shares on Facebook.

senses.definition: any of the units of equal value into which a company is divided that are sold to raise money. People who own shares receive part of the company’s profits.
examples: to have/hold/own shares
to buy/sell/trade shares
The company purchased 5.5m shares of the stock this week.
The company's shares fell 4.37 per cent.
Earnings per share are growing.
share in something They acquired shares in the company earlier this year.
a fall in share prices
70% of our share capital is in the hands of international investors.
a share certificate
The airline's shares closed (= finished trading for the day) up 8p at 171p.
American shares rose 2.7% the next day.
The company's shares slumped 11%.
Will this affect the value of my shares?
Hong Kong share prices plunged.
I have a few shares in the gas company.
I have some money in stocks and shares.
The company has issued four classes of shares.
The shares were trading at $1.10.
allegations of illegal share dealings

senses.definition: the broad curved blade (= metal cutting edge) of a plough
(more than) an amount of something that is considered to be reasonable or acceptable
examples: He has more than his fair share of problems.
I've had my fair share of success in the past.

senses.definition: the largest or best part of something when it is divided
a share of the available money or benefits that you believe you have a right to
examples: Scotland is demanding a larger share of the national cake.

senses.definition: to have, use or experience something at the same time as somebody else
examples: There isn't an empty table. Would you mind sharing?
share something to share a room/bed
Parents said there was insufficient room for the two schools to share space.
It's been 23 years since these four men shared a stage.
share something with somebody Sue shares a house with three other students.
Bob told Jess he wanted to share his life with her.

senses.definition: to have part of something while another person or other people also have part
examples: share something All members of the band equally share the band's profits.
share something with somebody He shared the pie with her.
The Hungarian king shared power with the Austrian emperor to form the Austro-Hungarian Empire.
share in something Each partner is entitled to share in the profits of the business.

senses.definition: to divide something between two or more people
examples: share something among/between somebody We shared the pizza between the four of us.
share something out among/between somebody Rita shared her money out among her six grandchildren.
share something out Profits are shared out yearly.
How do you share out three cakes among four people?
We shared the money equally between the three of us.

senses.definition: to give some of what you have to somebody else; to let somebody use something that is yours
examples: John had no brothers or sisters and wasn't used to sharing.
share something The conference is a good place to share information and exchange ideas.
share something with somebody This online resource will give farmers a new way to share knowledge with each other.
Eli shared his chocolate with the other kids.
experienced teachers willing to share their expertise with others
an environment where information is freely shared

senses.definition: to have the same feelings, ideas, experiences, etc. as somebody else
examples: share something to share a concern/an opinion
shared values
They shared a common interest in botany.
a view that is widely shared
They share a love of cinema.
His son doesn't share his passion for athletics.
share something with somebody We share many beliefs with followers of other religions.
People often share their political views with their parents.
share in something I didn't really share in her love of animals.
Personal experience of childbirth gives a dimension of knowledge that others cannot fully share.
These ideas are widely shared in the community.
She wished he would let her share his pain.
He shared in our enthusiasm for rowing.

senses.definition: to tell other people about your ideas, experiences, and feelings
examples: share something to share thoughts/ideas/feelings/memories
I did not find it easy to share my problems.
The two friends shared everything—they had no secrets.
Please share this on social media so we can get the word out.
I want to share the stories of several people I met.
Think of this as an opportunity to share your experiences.
The group listens while one person shares (= tells other people about their experiences, feelings, etc.).
share something with somebody Would you like to share your experience with the rest of the group?

senses.definition: to be equally involved in something or responsible for something
examples: share something Both drivers shared the blame for the accident.
share something with somebody Don't try to do everything yourself: you will need to share the load with your partner.
be shared between A and B Responsibility is shared between parents and teachers.
share in something I try to get the kids to share in the housework.

senses.definition: used to say that everyone should share things equally and in a fair way
if you talk to somebody about your problems and worries, instead of keeping them to yourself, they seem less serious
having a fine edge or point, especially of something that can cut or make a hole in something
examples: a sharp knife
Toys with sharp edges are not suitable for young children.
sharp teeth
Take a sheet of paper and a sharp pencil.

senses.definition: sudden, rapid and large
examples: a sharp drop in prices
a sharp rise in crime
a sharp increase in unemployment
the sharp decline in the value of the pound against the dollar
He heard a sharp intake of breath.
We need to give young criminals a short, sharp shock (= a punishment that is very unpleasant for a short time).

senses.definition: clear and definite
examples: a sharp outline
The photograph is not very sharp (= there are no clear contrasts between areas of light and shade).
She drew a sharp distinction between domestic and international politics.
In sharp contrast to her mood, the clouds were breaking up to reveal a blue sky.
The issue must be brought into sharper focus.
The image looks very sharp and nicely detailed.
The picture is surprisingly sharp and clear.
The sky was dark, with only the outlines of dockside warehouses standing sharp on the skyline.

senses.definition: quick to notice or understand things or to react
examples: to have sharp eyes
a girl of sharp intelligence
a sharp sense of humour
He kept a sharp lookout for any strangers.
It was very sharp of you to see that!
Her mind was as sharp as a razor.

senses.definition: critical or severe
examples: sharp criticism
Emma has a sharp tongue (= she often speaks in an unpleasant or unkind way).
sharp with somebody He was very sharp with me when I was late.
Her voice sounded rather sharp.
He has been exchanging sharp words with his architect.

senses.definition: loud, sudden and often high in tone
examples: She read out the list in sharp, clipped tones.
There was a sharp knock on the door.

senses.definition: very strong and sudden, often like being cut or badly hurt
examples: He winced as a sharp pain shot through his leg.
Polly felt a sharp pang of jealousy.

senses.definition: changing direction suddenly
examples: a sharp bend in the road
a sharp turn to the left

senses.definition: strong and slightly bitter
examples: The cheese has a distinctively sharp taste.
the pungent smell of burning rubber
Too much pulp produces a sour wine.
acrid smoke from burning tyres
The cheese has a distinctively sharp taste.
Raw cranberries are extremely sharp and must always be cooked with a little sugar.
The air had a sharp sooty smell.

senses.definition: used to describe a very cold or very severe frost or wind
clever but possibly dishonest
examples: His lawyer's a sharp operator.
The firm had to face some sharp practice from competing companies.

senses.definition: fashionable and new
examples: The consultants were a group of men in sharp suits.
Todd is a sharp dresser.

senses.definition: not full or round in shape
examples: a man with a thin face and sharp features (= a pointed nose and chin)

senses.definition: used after the name of a note to mean a note a semitone higher
examples: the Piano Sonata in C sharp minor

senses.definition: above the correct pitch (= how high or low a note sounds)
examples: That note sounded sharp.

senses.definition: not intelligent
examples: He's not exactly the sharpest knife in the drawer, is he?

senses.definition: the place or position of greatest difficulty or responsibility
examples: He started work at the sharp end of the business, as a salesman.

senses.definition: a female person or animal that has already been mentioned or is easily identified
examples: ‘What does your sister do?’ ‘She's a dentist.’
Doesn't she (= the woman we are looking at) look like Sue?
Think about a friend or family member. What kind of person is he or she?

senses.definition: it (used to refer to something not usually thought of as female)
examples: She's a big country.

senses.definition: an animal with a thick coat, kept on farms for its meat (called mutton or lamb) or its wool
examples: a flock of sheep
Sheep were grazing in the fields.
sheep farmers
These leaves are toxic to cattle and sheep.
My grandfather used to raise sheep in Australia.
The dogs herded the sheep into the pen.
a 4 000-acre sheep station in New South Wales
(figurative) He sees it as his duty to take care of the lost sheep of the world.

senses.definition: to imagine that sheep are jumping over a fence and to count them, as a way of getting to sleep
if people behave like sheep, they all do what the others are doing, without thinking for themselves
if you are going to be punished for doing something wrong, whether it is a big or small thing, you may as well do the big thing
to recognize the difference between people who are good at something, intelligent, etc. and those who are not
a person who seems to be friendly or not likely to cause any harm but is really an enemy
a large piece of thin cloth used on a bed to lie on or lie under
examples: Have you changed the sheets (= put clean sheets on the bed)?
He slid between the sheets and closed his eyes.
white bed sheets
Could you put some fresh sheets on the bed?
He threw back the sheets and rolled out of bed.
I pulled the sheet up over my nose.
I simply wrapped the sheet around her.
I slipped under the sheets and was asleep in an instant.
I threw a sheet over the sofa.

to have something as an advantage that will make it more likely that you will achieve something
examples: She may not win this year, but she does have youth on her side.

senses.definition: to know where you can get an advantage for yourself
to be forced to change from feeling pleased or satisfied to feeling disappointed or annoyed
examples: He’ll be laughing on the other side of his face when he reads my letter.

senses.definition: to fail to give your friends, family, etc. the help and support they expect, or to behave in a way that makes them disappointed
examples: You can always rely on Maggie—she’d never let the side down.
I felt I was letting the side down by not going to the wedding.

senses.definition: to be cheerful or positive about a bad situation, for example by thinking only of the advantages and not the disadvantages
examples: Look on the bright side. You managed to do more than I did.

senses.definition: to stay with somebody, especially in order to take care of them
in or from all directions; everywhere
examples: We realized we were surrounded on all sides.
Disaster threatens on every side.
She was bombarded with questions from all sides.

senses.definition: slightly too big, small, high, etc.
examples: These shoes are a little on the tight side.
Don’t you think you’re a bit on the short side to play basketball?

senses.definition: used to introduce the good points about somebody/something, especially after the bad points have been mentioned
examples: On the credit side, she’s always willing to work very late.

senses.definition: on the woman’s side of the family
out of your way
examples: I left my bags on one side.

senses.definition: to be dealt with later
examples: I put his complaint to one side until I had more time.
Leaving that to one side for a moment, are there any other questions?

senses.definition: younger or older than 40, 50, etc. years of age
being especially careful; taking no risks
examples: I took some extra cash just to be on the safe side.

senses.definition: in addition to your main job
examples: a mechanic who buys and sells cars on the side

senses.definition: secretly or illegally
examples: He's married but he has a girlfriend on the side.

senses.definition: served at the same time as the main part of the meal, but on a separate plate
in trouble with the police
the aspect of a situation that is the opposite of or contrasts with the one you have been talking about
with the top part turned to the top; in the correct, normal position
examples: I dropped my toast, but luckily it fell right side up.

senses.definition: close together and facing in the same direction
examples: There were two children ahead, walking side by side.
The two sat side by side on the bench.

senses.definition: together, without any difficulties
examples: We have been using both systems, side by side, for two years.
The two communities exist happily side by side.

senses.definition: used to refer to either of two opposite opinions on an issue
examples: The two countries are often on opposite sides of the fence when it comes to climate change.
There are arguments on both sides of the aisle.
On the other side of the fence there is anger at the reforms.
It is a proposal approved by people on both sides of the political fence.

senses.definition: to laugh a lot at somebody/something
to express support for somebody in an argument
examples: She didn't think it was wise to take sides in their argument.

senses.definition: to speak to somebody in private, especially in order to warn or tell them about something
before a particular time, event, age, etc.
examples: They aren't likely to arrive this side of midnight.

senses.definition: a person or thing that repeatedly annoys somebody or stops them from doing something
used to say that somebody can wait for something to happen or can wait before doing something
used to talk about two ways of looking at the same situation
the ability to see
examples: to lose your sight (= to become blind)
She has very good sight.
The disease has affected her sight.
He has very little sight in his right eye.
It's important that you have regular sight tests.
He's lost the sight of one eye.
His sight returned by degrees.
I think my sight is beginning to go.
The surgeons battled to save her sight.
This disease is the main cause of sight loss among those aged 50 and over.

senses.definition: the act of seeing somebody/something
examples: sight of somebody/something She kept sight of him in her mirror.
She caught sight of a car in the distance.
After ten days at sea, we had our first sight of land.
The mere sight of him makes me want to scream.
sight of somebody/something doing something The sight of him hobbling off so early in the match depressed everyone.
at the sight He laughed quietly to himself at the sight.
at the sight of somebody/something I have been known to faint at the sight of blood.
on sight The soldiers were given orders to shoot on sight (= as soon as they saw somebody).
Her knees went weak at the sight of him.
Thankfully, we were spared the sight of his naked body.
The mere sight of her sitting there made his heart beat faster.
I witnessed the awful sight of children drinking dirty water from puddles.
We will soon get our first sight of the Statue of Liberty.
I know her by sight (= recognize but do not know her).

senses.definition: the area or distance within which somebody can see or something can be seen
examples: in sight There was no one in sight.
They stole everything in sight.
The end is in sight (= will happen soon).
The goats ate everything in sight.
in sight of somebody/something At last we came in sight of a few houses.
A bicycle came into sight on the main road.
within sight They marched on and by the following afternoon the enemy was within sight.
within sight of somebody/something He sprinted ahead as they came within sight of the finishing line.
out of sight Leave any valuables in your car out of sight.
Keep out of sight (= stay where you cannot be seen).
out of somebody's sight She never lets her daughter out of her sight (= always keeps her where she can see her).
Get out of my sight! (= Go away!)
The boat disappeared from sight.
The house was hidden from sight behind some trees.
He looked up the street, but there was no one in sight.
Leave any valuables in your car out of sight.
The lake soon came into view.
The couple moved outside her field of vision (= total area you can see from a particular position).
He won't let the children leave his sight.
Her father was nowhere in sight.
The cricket ground was situated within sight of both village pubs.
They waited until the enemy was in plain sight.
He strode by, in full sight of the guards.
He didn't shoot until he had a clear sight of the goal.

senses.definition: a thing that you see or can see
examples: Roadside stalls are a common sight in the city.
It's a spectacular sight as the flamingos lift into the air.
The museum attempts to recreate the sights and sounds of wartime Britain.
He was a sorry sight, soaked to the skin and shivering.
The bird is now a rare sight in this country.
He became a familiar sight on the streets of Oxford.
The gardens were a beautiful sight to behold in the twilight.
They were unable to cite any studies to back up their claims.
She would never forget the sight of Machu Picchu appearing out of the mist.
He was the first European to sight the island later named Hispaniola.
Follow this link to reach the official site.
The company plans to site its new headquarters there.
The cottage had a delightful sea view.
It’s a spectacular sight as the flamingos lift into the air.
It was a delightful rural scene.
The tower offers a breathtaking panorama of Prague.
An appalling sight greeted her.
Dan's face was a welcome sight.
I'm not a pretty sight when I get out of bed in the morning.
The military parade was quite a sight.
This is a sight not often seen on concert stages in this country.

senses.definition: the interesting places, especially in a town or city, that are often visited by tourists
examples: We're going to Paris for the weekend to see the sights.
The next day I did the sights of the city.
It's best if you can get someone local to show you the sights.

senses.definition: a person or thing that looks silly, untidy, unpleasant, etc.
examples: She looks a sight in that hat!

senses.definition: a device that you look through to aim a gun, etc. or to look at something through a telescope, etc.
examples: He had the deer in his sights now.
to align the sights on the target
(figurative) Even as a young actress, she always had Hollywood firmly in her sights (= as her final goal).
Rossi has the defending champion in her sights in tomorrow's race.
She turned her sights on (= decided to examine) Florida's adoption laws.

senses.definition: when you first begin to consider something
examples: At first sight, it may look like a generous offer, but always read the small print.

senses.definition: when you see somebody/something for the first time
examples: It was love at first sight (= we fell in love the first time we saw each other).
We fell in love with the house at first sight.
He looked at first sight like a tourist.

senses.definition: to hate, etc. somebody/something very much
examples: I can't stand the sight of him!
We've shared an office for too long and we're sick of the sight of each other.

senses.definition: to appear, especially when moving gradually closer from a long way off
examples: A ship hove into sight.
Like a galleon in full sail, Cara hove into view.

senses.definition: in somebody’s opinion
examples: We are all equal in the sight of God.

senses.definition: to recognize somebody without knowing them well
to become no longer able to see somebody/something
examples: They finally lost sight of land.

senses.definition: to stop considering something; to forget something
examples: We must not lose sight of our original aim.

senses.definition: not pleasant to look at
examples: You should have seen him in his swimming trunks—not a pretty sight!

senses.definition: impossible for anyone to find or see
examples: I wanted to talk to him but he was nowhere to be found.
The children were nowhere to be seen.
A peace settlement is nowhere in sight (= is not likely in the near future).

senses.definition: used to say somebody will quickly be forgotten when they are no longer with you
to expect more/less from a situation
examples: If they can’t afford such a big house, they’ll just have to lower their sights a little.
After failing to get into university, he lowered his sights and got a job in a shop.

senses.definition: to decide that you want something and to try very hard to get it
examples: She's set her sights on getting into Harvard.
I had set my sights on a career in journalism.
He says he wants to win the trophy, but I think he's setting his sights too high.
She has her sights set on becoming a writer.

senses.definition: very much better; much too good, etc.
examples: She's done a darn sight better than I have.
It's worth a damn sight more than I thought.

senses.definition: a person or thing that you are pleased to see; something that is very pleasant to look at
if you buy something sight unseen, you do not have an opportunity to see it before you buy it
examples: I bought it, sight unseen.

senses.definition: an event, an action, a fact, etc. that shows that something exists, is happening or may happen in the future
examples: Looking back, I should have seen the signs.
a clear/visible sign
an encouraging sign
a positive sign
The fact that he didn't say ‘no’ immediately is a good sign.
If I had noticed the warning signs, none of this would have happened.
Early signs point to business improving.
sign of somebody/something This move will be seen as a sign of weakness.

Headaches may be a sign of stress.
There is no sign of John anywhere.
Soldiers swarmed the city looking for any sign of her.
There was no sign of life in the house (= there seemed to be nobody there).

I hope this incident isn't a sign of things to come.
Get this test if you have signs and symptoms of diabetes.
He is reading the signs all wrong.
at a sign of something Call the police at the first sign of trouble.
sign of doing something The gloomy weather shows no sign of improving.
sign of somebody/something doing something There is little sign of this happening in the immediate future.
sign (that)… If an interview is too easy, it's a sure sign that you haven't got the job.
There were no outward signs that anything was wrong.
Headaches may be a sign of stress.
They gave no indication as to how the work should be done.
Symptoms include a sore throat.

The dove is a universal symbol of peace.
the economic indicators
Chest pains can be a warning signal of heart problems.

His face betrayed no sign of emotion.
By now the fish was showing signs of distress.

Look carefully for signs of damp.
The first signs of spring appeared.
Strong dislikes of foods are early signs of pregnancy.

senses.definition: a piece of paper, wood or metal that has writing or a picture on it that gives you information, instructions, a warning, etc.
examples: to put up/post a sign
to carry/hold a sign
a street/stop sign
a shop/pub sign
a traffic sign

There was a 'Closed' sign in the window.
Follow the signs for the city centre.
Some of the marchers were holding up signs and placards.

This sign indicates that cycling is allowed.
signs warning against trespass

senses.definition: a movement or sound that you make to tell somebody something
examples: He gave a thumbs-up sign (= to show approval/agreement).
sign from somebody She was waiting for some kind of sign from him.

as a sign of something He gave a slight bow as a sign of respect.
sign to do something She shook her head in a desperate sign to tell the child to remain silent.
sign for somebody to do something She nodded as a sign for us to sit down.

to make the sign of the cross (= an act of moving one hand in the shape of a cross, done by Christians to show respect for God or by a priest to bless somebody/something)

the sign for ‘woman’ in sign language

senses.definition: a mark used to represent something, especially in mathematics
examples: a plus/minus sign (= +/−)
a dollar/pound sign (= $/£)
sign for something the sign for ‘square root’

a T-shirt with a peace sign on it

senses.definition: a star sign (= one of the twelve signs of the zodiac)
examples: What sign are you?

people born under the sign of Gemini
the twelve astrological signs

senses.definition: something that you feel shows what things are like now, especially how bad they are
examples: The increasing number of people owning guns is an alarming sign of the times.

senses.definition: to write your name on a document, letter, etc. to show that you have written it, that you agree with what it says, or that it is real
examples: Sign here, please.
sign something to sign an agreement/a deal/a contract
to sign a document/statement/declaration/form
to sign a petition/a bill/ an order
to sign a cheque

I'm going to his office now to sign the papers.

sign yourself + noun He signed himself ‘Jimmy’.

The legislation has been signed by the president.

This is the contract you will be required to sign.
a first edition of the book, personally signed by the author

senses.definition: to arrange for somebody, for example a sports player or musician, to sign a contract agreeing to work for your company; to sign a contract agreeing to work for a company
examples: sign somebody United have just signed a new goalie.
to sign a player
sign for something He signed for United yesterday.
sign with something The band signed with Virgin Records.
sign (somebody) to something She was the first musician signed to the new record label.

senses.definition: to make a request or tell somebody to do something by using a sign, especially a hand movement
examples: sign to somebody (to do something) The hotel manager signed to the porter to pick up my case.
sign for somebody to do something The police officer signed for us to stop.
sign that… The police officer signed that we were to stop.
signsomebody to do something He signed his troops to move out.

senses.definition: to use sign language to communicate with somebody
examples: She learnt to sign to help her deaf child.
sign something An increasing number of plays are now being signed.

senses.definition: definite, because all the legal documents have been signed
to sign a document to show that you have agreed to buy something or do something
examples: Just sign on the dotted line and the car is yours.

senses.definition: to make a promise never to drink alcohol
a movement or sound that you make to give somebody information, instructions, a warning, etc.
examples: a danger/warning/distress signal
at a signal At an agreed signal they left the room.
signal to somebody She made an impatient signal to him, but he ignored her.
signal to do something He thought he had heard the referee's signal to proceed.
signal for somebody to do something The siren was a signal for everyone to leave the building.
signal (that)… We spotted the scout's signal that four enemy soldiers were coming towards us.
signal from somebody Wait for the signal from the leader of your group.
When I give the signal, run!
(North American English) All I get is a busy signal when I dial his number (= his phone is being used).
hand signals (= movements that cyclists make with their hands to tell other people that they are going to stop, turn, etc.)

The nerves carry these signals to the brain.

senses.definition: a piece of equipment that uses different coloured lights to tell drivers to go slower, stop, etc., used especially on railways and roads
examples: The traffic signals were on red.
a stop signal

senses.definition: a series of electrical waves that carry sounds, pictures or messages, for example to a radio, television or mobile phone
examples: radio signals
TV signals
a digital signal
a high-frequency signal
a radar signal
to emit a signal
to detect/pick up signals
I couldn't get a signal on my phone.
The signal is received by three different antennas at slightly different times.
The satellite is used for transmitting signals around the world.
signal from something The signal from the transmitter seems to have been boosted.

The digital signal travels down wires to the server.
The signal is scrambled into code before it is sent.
This equipment can detect very low frequency signals.
a faint signal from the satellite

senses.definition: an event, an action, a fact, etc. that shows that something exists or is likely to happen
examples: signal (that)… The rise in inflation is a clear signal that the government's policies are not working.
The court has given a strong signal that it disagrees with the government's position.
signal of something Chest pains can be a warning signal of heart problems.
Reducing prison sentences would send the wrong signals to criminals.
Headaches may be a sign of stress.
They gave no indication as to how the work should be done.
Symptoms include a sore throat.
The rise in inflation was just one symptom of the poor state of the economy.
The dove is a universal symbol of peace.
the economic indicators
Chest pains can be a warning signal of heart problems.
Interviewers quickly learn to pick up non-verbal signals.

Try to read the signals coming from the patient.
the signals that can indicate danger

senses.definition: to make a movement or sound to give somebody a message, an order, etc.
examples: Don't fire until I signal.
signal to somebody She signalled to the man, who immediately came over to her.
signal for something A woman was leaning out a top-floor window, signaling for help.
signal to somebody for something He signalled to the waiter for the bill.
signal to/for somebody to do something He signalled to us to join him.
The patrolman signalled for her to stop.
signal somebody to do something She signalled him to follow.
signal something The referee signalled a foul.
signal (that)… She signalled (that) it was time to leave.
signal which, what, etc… You must signal which way you are going to turn.
I saw her signal frantically to us.
Many animals use their tails to signal.
When I'm ready I'll signal with a flashlight.

senses.definition: to show that your vehicle is going to change direction, by using lights or your arm
examples: Did you signal before you turned right?
signal something to signal left/right
signal (that)… I signalled that I was going to turn left.

senses.definition: to be a sign that something exists or is likely to happen
examples: This announcement signalled a clear change of policy.
The scandal surely signals the end of his political career.
These events appeared to signal the end of an era.
These changes clearly signal the end of the welfare state as we know it.
A fall in demand does not necessarily signal the death of the industry.

senses.definition: to do something to make your feelings or opinions known
examples: signal something He signalled his discontent by refusing to vote.
signal (that)… She has signalled (that) she is willing to stand as a candidate.

senses.definition: large or important enough to have an effect or to be noticed
examples: There are no significant differences between the two groups of students.
Your work has shown a significant improvement.
a significant increase/decrease/reduction/loss
a significant amount/number/part/portion
significant change/progress

These views are held by a significant proportion of the population.

The offender was assessed as posing a significant risk to others.
it is significant that… It is significant that girls generally do better in examinations than boys.

The size of the garden was a significant factor in her decision to buy the house.

senses.definition: having a particular meaning
examples: The fact that her remarks were leaked to the media in advance is highly significant.
it is significant that… It is significant that he changed his will only days before his death.
This year's event is particularly significant as it takes place on the centenary of his birth.
significant to/for somebody rituals which are deeply significant to Christians
November 16th will always be an especially significant day for us, thanks to the birth of our second grandchild.

senses.definition: having a special or secret meaning that is not understood by everyone
examples: a significant look/smile

senses.definition: in a way that is large or important enough to have an effect on something or to be noticed
examples: significantly higher/lower/larger/smaller

to differ/vary/change significantly
significantly greater/better
significantly more/less/fewer
Profits have increased significantly over the past few years.
The high school dropout rate has significantly decreased since then.
The risks can be significantly reduced by paying close attention to diet and lifestyle.
Your decision will significantly affect your future.
These services will significantly improve the quality of life for older people in the area.
Einstein contributed significantly to the early development of quantum mechanics.
Food prices are significantly lower in the US.
Results showed that depression was significantly related to traumatic life events.
Variation in dialect was not significantly correlated with geographical distance.
Constant use of alcohol significantly alters the structure of the brain.
All traditional risk factors were significantly associated with both outcomes.

senses.definition: in a way that has a particular meaning
examples: Significantly, he did not deny that there might be an election.
Perhaps significantly, many of their illegal activities were not considered as crime.

senses.definition: in a way that has a special or secret meaning
examples: She paused significantly before she answered.

senses.definition: a complete lack of noise or sound
examples: Their footsteps echoed in the silence.
A scream broke the silence of the night.
I need absolute silence when I'm working.
Celeste's voice penetrated the silence.
She filled the silence with music.
Silence reigned.
We sat in complete silence, save for the ticking of the clock.
a silence punctuated only by the occasional sniff from the children

senses.definition: a situation when nobody is speaking
examples: an embarrassed/awkward/uncomfortable silence
a moment’s stunned silence

They finished their meal in total silence.
She lapsed into silence again.
There was a deafening silence (= one that is very noticeable).
a two-minute silence in honour of those who had died
Her accusations reduced him to silence.
He’s not one to suffer in silence! (= to suffer without telling somebody)
There was a moment of uncomfortable silence.
They observed a two-minute silence in memory of the children.
A heavy silence lingered in the air.
A stunned silence greeted her announcement.
A sudden silence fell over the room.
He lapsed into a sullen silence.
He thought for a moment, the silence lengthening.
She fell into long, brooding silences.
The boys were stunned into silence by this news.
The rest of the trip passed in relative silence.
There was a moment's silence before she replied.
They ate their breakfast in silence.
They walked in companionable silence.
We sat and watched in awed silence as she performed.

senses.definition: a situation in which somebody refuses to talk about something or to answer questions
examples: She broke her public silence in a TV interview.
silence (on something) The company's silence on the subject has been taken as an admission of guilt.
the right to silence (= the legal right not to say anything when you are arrested)

I took her silence as a no.

senses.definition: a situation in which people do not communicate with each other by letter or phone
examples: The phone call came after months of silence.

senses.definition: a situation when people do not say anything, but feel embarrassed or uncomfortable
an occasion when nobody speaks, although people are aware that there are feelings or thoughts to express
examples: There was a pregnant pause before she replied.

senses.definition: it is often best not to say anything
where there is little or no sound; making little or no sound
examples: At last the traffic fell silent.
The streets were silent and deserted.
The new bus is virtually silent.
As darkness began to fall, the cannon fell silent.

senses.definition: not speaking
examples: to remain/stay/keep silent

He gave me the silent treatment (= did not speak to me because he was angry).

The mayor was silent for a moment.
Len remained obstinately silent.
She sat silent throughout the meal.
I could not keep silent any longer.
The room grew silent as the men entered.
We were asked to remain silent for two minutes.

senses.definition: not expressed with words or sound
examples: a silent prayer/protest

senses.definition: written but not pronounced
examples: The ‘b’ in ‘lamb’ is silent.

senses.definition: with pictures but no sound
examples: a silent film/movie
stars of the silent screen

senses.definition: not talking very much
examples: He's the strong silent type.

senses.definition: not giving information about something; refusing to speak about something
examples: The report is strangely silent on this issue.
the right to remain silent (= the legal right not to say anything when you are arrested)

This is a subject about which the official documents are ominously silent.

senses.definition: fine soft thread produced by silkworms
examples: The caterpillar spins the silk around its entire body.

senses.definition: a type of fine smooth cloth made from silk thread; a piece of this cloth
examples: a silk dress/blouse/scarf/tie/sari
silk stockings
made of pure silk

fine silks produced in Italy
a drawing room decorated in rich blue and purple silks
the bright silks of saris

senses.definition: thread made of silk used for sewing
clothes made of silk, especially the coloured shirts worn by people riding horses in a race (= jockeys)
examples: ladies in silks and satins

senses.definition: a type of lawyer who represents the government (= a King’s Counsel / Queen’s Counsel)
examples: to take silk (= to become this type of lawyer)

senses.definition: (you won't) succeed in making something good out of material that does not seem very good at all
showing a lack of thought, understanding, or judgement
examples: a silly idea/question/name

It sounds silly, I know, but think about it.

You silly boy!
it is silly to do something It would have been silly to pretend that I wasn't upset.
it is silly of somebody to do something It would be silly of me to say no.

senses.definition: stupid or embarrassing, especially in a way that is more typical of a child than an adult
examples: a silly sense of humour
a silly game

I feel silly in these clothes.
She had a silly grin on her face.

senses.definition: an amount of snow that falls in one particular place or at one particular time
examples: the first snows of winter
the snows of Mount Kilimanjaro

senses.definition: extremely clean, pure, etc.
when it snows, snow falls from the sky
examples: It's been snowing heavily all day.

It was still snowing outside.

senses.definition: to impress somebody a lot by the things you say, especially if these are not true or not sincere
examples: He really snowed me with all his talk of buying a Porsche.

senses.definition: to be unable to leave a place because of heavy snow
examples: We were snowed in for two days.

senses.definition: to have more things, especially work, than you feel able to deal with
examples: I'd love to come but I'm completely snowed under at the moment.

senses.definition: to be blocked with snow
to such a great degree
examples: Don't look so angry.
There's no need to worry so.

That wasn't so bad, was it?
so… (that)… She spoke so quietly (that) I could hardly hear her.
What is it that's so important it can't wait five minutes?

She gets so caught up in her fame that she neglects her true friends.

so… as to do something I'm not so stupid as to believe that.

You should use stronger thread to sew the button back on.
It is unsurprising that they were so successful.
I was worried about you, so I thought I'd just give you a call.
Collect the seeds now to sow next season.

senses.definition: very; extremely

We've worked so hard to get to this point.

senses.definition: not to the same degree

senses.definition: used to show the size, amount or number of something
examples: The fish was about so big (= said when using your hands to show the size).

senses.definition: used to refer back to something that has already been mentioned
examples: ‘Is he coming?’ ‘I hope so.’
‘Did they mind?’ ‘I don't think so.’

senses.definition: also
examples: Times have changed and so have I.

senses.definition: used to agree that something is true, especially when you are surprised
examples: ‘You were there, too.’ ‘So I was—I'd forgotten.’

senses.definition: used, often with a negative, before adjectives and noun phrases to emphasize something that you are saying
examples: He is so not the right person for you.

senses.definition: used, especially by children, to say that what somebody says is not the case and the opposite is true
examples: ‘You're not telling the truth, are you?’ ‘I am, so!’

senses.definition: used when you are showing somebody how to do something or telling them how something happened
examples: Stand with your arms out, so.

senses.definition: used at the end of a list to show that it continues in the same way
examples: We discussed everything—when to go, what to see and so on.

senses.definition: used to give an important extra reason why something is true
examples: His achievement is remarkable; all the more so because he had no help at all.

senses.definition: used after a number, an amount, etc. to show that it is not exact
examples: There were twenty or so (= about twenty) people there.

senses.definition: with the intention of doing something
examples: We went early so as to get good seats.

senses.definition: used to show that you accept something and will not try to change it or cannot change it
examples: If he doesn't want to be involved, then so be it.

senses.definition: used to show that you have finished talking about something
examples: So much for the situation in Germany. Now we turn our attention to France.

senses.definition: used to suggest that something has not been successful or useful
examples: So much for that idea!

senses.definition: in such a way that
examples: The programme has been so organized that none of the talks overlap.

senses.definition: used to show the reason for something
examples: It was still painful, so I went to see a doctor.
You should use stronger thread to sew the button back on.
It is unsurprising that they were so successful.
I was worried about you, so I thought I'd just give you a call.
Collect the seeds now to sow next season.

senses.definition: used to show the purpose of something
examples: But I gave you a map so you wouldn't get lost!

senses.definition: used to show the result of something
examples: Nothing more was heard from him so that we began to wonder if he was dead.

senses.definition: used to introduce a comment or a question
examples: So, let's see. What do we need to take?

senses.definition: used to introduce the next part of a story
examples: So after shouting and screaming for an hour she walked out in tears.

senses.definition: used to show that you think something is not important, especially after somebody has criticized you for it
examples: So I had a couple of drinks on the way home. What's wrong with that?

senses.definition: used when you are making a final statement
examples: So, that's it for today.

senses.definition: used in questions to refer to something that has just been said
examples: So there's nothing we can do about it?

senses.definition: used to introduce an answer to a question, an explanation or a statement
examples: So, I've been working on a new project.

senses.definition: used when stating that two events, situations, etc. are similar
examples: Just as large companies are having to cut back, so small businesses are being forced to close.

senses.definition: used to show that you think something is not important, especially after somebody has criticized you for it
examples: ‘He's fifteen years younger than you!’ ‘So what?’

senses.definition: to make progress in what you are doing

examples: It cost somewhere around two thousand dollars.

senses.definition: a place that you do not know or do not mention by name
examples: We need to find somewhere to live.
I know somewhere we can go.

senses.definition: a person’s male child
examples: their four-year-old son
my teenage/eldest son
her young/baby son

the birth/death of a son
son of somebody He's the son of an Oxford professor.

Maine & Sons, Grocers (= the name of a company on a sign)

senses.definition: a friendly form of address that is used by an older man to a young man or boy
examples: Well, son, how can I help you?

senses.definition: a man who belongs to a particular place or country, etc.

a native son of Philadelphia

senses.definition: used by a priest to address a boy or man
Jesus Christ as the second member of the Trinity

senses.definition: a performer, politician, sports player, etc., who is popular where they were born
(in the US) a candidate for president who is supported by his or her own state in the first part of a campaign
from one generation of a family to the next
used to say that a son’s character or behaviour is similar to that of his father
a person who leaves home and wastes their money and time on a life of pleasure, but who later is sorry about this and returns home
a short piece of music with words that you sing
examples: a love/pop/rock song

the theme song to the hit TV show
a hit/popular/traditional song
to write/record/perform/play a song
to listen to/hear a song

the best song on the album
songs about love
a song of praise/love
song by somebody a collection of songs by various artists

He released an album of cover songs.

a Hungarian folk song
a protest song written in the sixties
the theme song from ‘The Godfather’
the title song from the Beatles' album ‘Help!’
an old song she'd learned from her mother
a song called 'If I Only Had Time'

an orchestral version of the song
The album contains five original songs and six covers.
song titles/​lyrics

senses.definition: songs in general; music for singing
examples: The story is told through song and dance.
Suddenly he burst into song (= started to sing).
I hate it when characters break into song (= start to sing) for no apparent reason.
in song Their voices were raised in song.
Important historical events were commemorated in song.

senses.definition: the musical sounds that birds make
examples: the song of the blackbird

senses.definition: very cheaply; at a low price
examples: She bought the painting for a song.
The property is going for a song because they need to sell it fast.

senses.definition: working or performing well
examples: The whole team was on song.

senses.definition: to show that you are in agreement with each other by saying the same things in public
if you make a song and dance about something, you complain or talk about it too much when this is not necessary
examples: She gives generously to charity without making a song and dance about it.

senses.definition: a long explanation about something, or excuse for something
in a short time from now; a short time after something else has happened
examples: She sold the house soon after her husband died.
Soon afterwards, he joined a youth theatre group.
I'd love to meet up again sometime soon.

See you soon!

We’ll be home soon./We’ll soon be home.
I'll be back soon.

He promises to visit again soon.
Coming soon to a cinema/theater near you: 'War of the Wizards II'.

The two men soon discovered they had much in common.
The trial is expected to start soon.
Soon thereafter (= soon after that), she returned to Tanzania.

senses.definition: early; quickly
examples: How soon can you get here?
We'll deliver the goods as soon as we can.
Please send it as soon as possible.
Do you really have to go so soon?
It's too soon to say what caused this.
Next Monday is the soonest we can deliver.
The sooner we set off, the sooner we will arrive.
All too soon the party was over.
They arrived home sooner than expected.
The note said, ‘Call Bill soonest’ (= as soon as possible).

senses.definition: used in negative sentences and questions to refer to the near future
examples: Will she be back anytime soon?

senses.definition: used to say that you would equally well like to do something as do something else that has been suggested
examples: I'd just as soon stay at home as go out tonight.

senses.definition: to prefer to do something (than do something else)
examples: She'd sooner share a house with other students than live at home with her parents.

senses.definition: a bad situation will pass or be forgotten most quickly if nothing more is said about it
used to say that something was, or will be, done immediately
used to say that something happens immediately after something else
examples: No sooner had she said it than she burst into tears.
They have sold scarcely any copies of the book.
I barely recognized her.
His words were barely audible.
I can hardly believe it.
I hardly can believe it.
I can’t hardly believe it.
We had hardly/​scarcely/​barely sat down at the table, when the doorbell rang.
Hardly/​Scarcely had we sat down at the table, when the doorbell rang.
I scarcely had time to ring the bell before the door opened.
No sooner had we sat down at the table than the doorbell rang.
She hardly (ever) sees her parents these days.
She barely sees her parents these days.

senses.definition: very soon; as soon as possible
examples: ‘When shall I tell him?’ ‘The sooner the better.’

senses.definition: at some time in the future, even if you are not sure exactly when
examples: Sooner or later you will have to make a decision.

senses.definition: after a short time rather than after a long time
examples: We urged them to sort out the problem sooner rather than later.

senses.definition: feeling sad and ashamed about something that has been done
examples: sorry about something We're very sorry about the damage to your car.
I'm sorry about the mess—I haven't had a chance to tidy up yet.
sorry for something She is obviously deeply sorry for what she has done.
We are sorry for the delay and hope the train will be moving again shortly.
sorry for doing something He says he's really sorry for taking the car without asking.
sorry (that)… She was sorry that she'd lost her temper.
I am so sorry that this happened.
If you say you're sorry we'll forgive you.
I'm so sorry I'm late.
I'm terribly sorry for letting you down.
I'm very sorry about that.
I do apologize. I'll get you another cup.
I must apologize for keeping you waiting.
We would like to apologize on behalf of the management.
We would like to offer our apologies for the inconvenience
Please accept our apologies for the delay.
That's all right.
That's OK.
No problem.
Don't worry about it.
It's fine, really.

senses.definition: feeling sad and showing sympathy
examples: sorry (that)… I'm sorry that your husband lost his job.
sorry to do something We're sorry to hear that your father's in hospital again.
I was sorry to see him go.
sorry about somebody/something No one is sorrier than I am about what happened.
I am sorry about the way Dad treated you.
I'm sorry about your mother. I do hope she'll soon be feeling better.
sorry for something I'm very sorry for your loss (= expressing sympathy when somebody has died).
I'm sorry you're not well. I hope you feel better soon.
I am sorry to hear that.
That's bad luck.
How awful for you.
I'm sorry for your loss

senses.definition: feeling disappointed about something and wishing you had done something different or had not done something
examples: sorry (that)… She was sorry that she'd lost contact with Mary.
I'll make you sorry you were ever born!
You'll be sorry if I catch you!
sorry to do something I was genuinely sorry to be leaving college.
She was almost sorry to stop work.

senses.definition: very sad or bad, especially making you feel pity or disapproval
examples: The business is in a sorry state.
They were a sorry sight when they eventually got off the boat.

senses.definition: to be sad or feel sympathy for somebody
examples: He decided to help Jan as he felt sorry for her.

senses.definition: used to say that it is wiser to be too careful than to act too quickly and do something you may later wish you had not
examples: She decided to avoid travelling at night. Better safe than sorry.

senses.definition: to feel unhappy; to be sad about yourself because you are suffering
examples: Stop feeling sorry for yourself and think about other people for a change.
Mitch felt slightly sorry for himself.

senses.definition: used when you are apologizing for something
examples: I'm sorry, I forgot.
Oh, I'm sorry. Have I taken the one you wanted?
I'm sorry. I can't make it tomorrow.
I'm sorry to interrupt but there's an urgent call for you.
I am sorry to disappoint you.
I'm awfully sorry Jane can't come with us.
I'm sorry about the noise.
I'm terribly sorry. I didn't catch your name.

senses.definition: used for disagreeing with somebody or politely saying ‘no’
examples: I'm sorry, I don't agree.
I'm sorry, I'd rather you didn't go.

senses.definition: used for introducing bad news
examples: I'm sorry to have to tell you you've failed.

senses.definition: used for saying that something is disappointing
examples: He didn't accept the job, I'm sorry to say.

senses.definition: used when you are apologizing for something
examples: Sorry I'm late!
Did I stand on your foot? Sorry!
Sorry to bother you, but could I speak to you for a moment?
Sorry, we don't allow dogs in the house.
He didn't even say sorry.

senses.definition: used for asking somebody to repeat something that you have not heard clearly
examples: Sorry? Could you repeat the question?

senses.definition: used for correcting yourself when you have said something wrong
examples: Take the first turning, sorry, the third turning on the right.

senses.definition: a group or type of people or things that are similar in a particular way
examples: sort of somebody/something ‘What sort of music do you like?’ ‘Oh, all sorts.’

(informal) There are all sorts of activities (= many different ones) for kids at the campsite.
(informal) What sort of price did you want to pay? (= approximately how much)
(informal) What sort of time do you call this? (= I'm very angry that you have come so late.)

(informal) Tracey has been causing her mother all sorts of problems (= many different ones).
each/​one/​every kind of animal
all/​many/​other sorts of animals.
This kind of question often appears in the exam.

These kinds of questions often appear in the exam.
These sorts of behaviour are not acceptable.
These kinds of question often appear in the exam.
These sort of things don’t happen in real life.

There are many different sorts of animal on the island.
What kind of camera is this?
What kind/​kinds of cameras do you sell?

senses.definition: a particular type of person

senses.definition: the process of putting data in a particular order
examples: to do a sort

senses.definition: used to say that you think somebody’s behaviour is very strange or unusual but that everyone is different and likes different things
examples: ‘They spent their honeymoon mountain climbing.’ ‘Oh well, it takes all sorts!’

senses.definition: used to emphasize that the situation is very different from what has been said
examples: ‘I was terrible!’ ‘You were nothing of the sort.’

senses.definition: used when you are saying that something is not a good example of a particular type of thing
examples: He offered us an apology of sorts.

senses.definition: ill or upset
examples: She was tired and out of sorts by the time she arrived home.

senses.definition: to some extent but in a way that you cannot easily describe
examples: She sort of pretends that she doesn't really care.

senses.definition: used for describing something in a not very exact way
examples: I had a sort of feeling that he wouldn't come.

senses.definition: to arrange things in groups or in a particular order according to their type, etc.; to separate things of one type from others

sort something by something Events are sorted by date and category.

senses.definition: to deal with a problem successfully or organize something/somebody properly

senses.definition: to show or prove who is brave, skilful, etc. and who is not

senses.definition: the spiritual part of a person, believed to exist after death

senses.definition: a person’s inner character, containing their true thoughts and feelings

senses.definition: a person of a particular type

senses.definition: a person
