senses.definition: a type of music that expresses strong emotions, made popular by African American musicians

senses.definition: to tell somebody your deepest and most private feelings
with all your energy
examples: She committed herself body and soul to fighting for the cause.

senses.definition: used to show respect when you are talking about somebody who is dead
good for you, even if it seems unpleasant

senses.definition: with a lot of energy and enthusiasm
examples: They threw themselves heart and soul into the project.

senses.definition: to stay alive with just enough of the food, clothing, etc. that you need

senses.definition: the liveliest and funniest person at a party, etc.
to do anything, even something really bad or dishonest, in return for money, success or power
something that you can hear
examples: a loud/soft/faint sound
a high/low sound

senses.definition: continuous rapid movements (called vibrations) that travel through air or water and can be heard when they reach a person’s or an animal’s ear

senses.definition: what you can hear coming from a television, radio, etc., or as part of a film

examples: I like their sound.

senses.definition: the idea or impression that you get of somebody/something from what somebody says or what you read

senses.definition: a narrow passage of water that joins two larger areas of water
examples: Plymouth Sound

senses.definition: to like talking a lot or too much, usually without wanting to listen to other people
examples: She’s much too fond of the sound of her own voice.

senses.definition: near enough to be able to hear something
examples: a house within sound of the sea

senses.definition: to give a particular impression when heard or read about

sound like somebody/something The pioneering technique sounds like something out of a science fiction film.

sound as if/as though… I hope I don’t sound as if/as though I’m criticizing you.

senses.definition: giving the impression of having a particular sound
examples: an Italian-sounding name
fine-sounding words

senses.definition: to produce a sound; to make something such as a musical instrument produce a sound
examples: The bell sounded for the end of the class.

senses.definition: to pronounce something

senses.definition: to measure the depth of the sea or a lake by using a line with a weight attached, or an electronic instrument
to be very similar to something
examples: Their latest single sounds suspiciously like the last one.

senses.definition: to express feelings or opinions of a particular kind
examples: She sounded a note of warning in her speech.

senses.definition: used to agree to a suggestion that you think is good
a liquid food made by boiling meat, vegetables, etc. in water, often eaten as the first course of a meal
examples: a bowl/cup of soup
chicken/vegetable/tomato soup
a soup spoon/bowl/plate
(British English) a tin/packet of soup

hearty vegetable soup
the Chinese delicacy of shark fin soup
the emergence of life from the primordial soup on the earth

senses.definition: from beginning to end
examples: She told me the whole story from soup to nuts.

senses.definition: in trouble
examples: We're all in the soup now.

senses.definition: a place, person or thing that you get something from
examples: renewable energy sources

from a source Funding came from a wide variety of sources.

a cheap source of labour
a fertile source of ideas
a lucrative source of income
a reliable source of advice
a rich source of vitamins
a source of energy/​food/​light
an independent source of funding
to develop new sources of revenue

senses.definition: a person, book or document that provides information, especially for study, a piece of written work or news

his refusal to reveal the identity of a confidential source

senses.definition: a person or thing that causes or provides something

a potential source of conflict
a constant source of irritation

senses.definition: the place where a river or stream starts

senses.definition: at the place or the point that something comes from or begins

senses.definition: in or towards the south

senses.definition: a south wind blows from the south
examples: A mild south wind blew all day.

senses.definition: towards the south
examples: This room faces south.

senses.definition: nearer to the south than something
examples: They live ten miles south of Bristol.

senses.definition: less or lower than something
examples: The drug is achieving revenues just south of $1 billion per quarter.

senses.definition: to or in the south of a country
examples: They've gone to live down south.

senses.definition: the direction that is on your right when you watch the sun rise; one of the four main points of the compass
examples: Which way is south?
warmer weather coming from the south
a south-facing garden
to the south (of…) He lives to the south of (= further south than) the city.
views of distant mountains to north and south

senses.definition: the southern part of a country, a region or the world
examples: birds flying to the south for the winter
in the south Houses are less expensive in the North than in the South (= of the country).

senses.definition: the southern states of the US
examples: The South used to rely heavily on agriculture.

senses.definition: the poorer countries in the southern half of the world
examples: The South comprises many diverse countries.
the vast informal economies of the Global South

senses.definition: located in the south or facing south; connected with or typical of the south part of the world or a region
examples: the southern slopes of the mountains
southern Spain
a southern accent
the southern part of the region

southern French cuisine
the company's global expansion into the southern hemisphere

senses.definition: the area outside the earth’s atmosphere where all the other planets and stars are

the possibility of visitors from outer space
space exploration/travel
a space flight/mission
the US space program

the film's famous tagline 'In space no one can hear you scream'

these wonderful pictures from the edge of space

technology that made space travel possible

senses.definition: an area or a place that is empty
examples: an empty space
a large/small/narrow/wide space

First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips.

The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt.
As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away. This causes the solid material to sink to the bottom, forming a layer of paper.
At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper/…dry the paper at the same time.

senses.definition: a quantity of a substance, such as solid glue (= a sticky substance), that is sold in a small container with round ends and straight sides, and can be pushed further out of the container as it is used

a handle used to change the gears of a vehicle
a baton, used by the person who conducts an orchestra
criticism or severe words
examples: The referee got a lot of stick from the home fans.

senses.definition: country areas, a long way from cities
examples: We live out in the sticks.

senses.definition: a person
examples: He's not such a bad old stick.

senses.definition: to be in a difficult situation when any action you take will have bad results
the use or threat of force or power
examples: The authorities used quiet persuasion instead of the big stick.

senses.definition: if you use the carrot and stick approach, you persuade somebody to try harder by offering them a reward if they do, or a punishment if they do not
examples: The emphasis is on the carrot of incentive rather than the stick of taxes.
to adopt the carrot-and-stick approach
He decided to use the carrot and stick approach.

senses.definition: to be the person in a group who is chosen or forced to perform an unpleasant duty or task
to understand something in the wrong way
a fact, an argument, etc. that is used in order to blame or punish somebody
to suddenly move from your house and go to live somewhere else
examples: He upped sticks and went back to France.

senses.definition: to fix something to something else, usually with a sticky substance; to become fixed to something in this way
examples: stick something + adv./prep. He stuck a stamp on the envelope.
We used glue to stick the broken pieces together.
I stuck the photos into an album.
(+ adv./prep.) Her wet clothes were sticking to her body.
The glue's useless—the pieces just won't stick.
Her wet hair was sticking to her head.
I forgot to stick a stamp on the envelope.

senses.definition: to become fixed in one position and impossible to move
examples: This drawer keeps sticking.
stick in something The key has stuck in the lock.

senses.definition: to push something, usually a sharp object, into something; to be pushed into something
examples: stick something + adv./prep. The nurse stuck the needle into my arm.
Don't stick your fingers through the bars of the cage.
+ adv./prep. I found a nail sticking in the tyre.
He simply stuck a pin in at random among the names of the candidates.
She stuck a finger into the sugar bowl.
The little boy had stuck his head through the railings.

senses.definition: to put something in a place, especially quickly or carelessly
examples: Stick your bags down there.
He stuck his hands in his pockets and strolled off.
Can you stick this on the noticeboard?
Peter stuck his head around the door and said, ‘Coffee, anyone?’
He stuck the note through her letter box.
(informal) Stick 'em up! (= Put your hands above your head—I have a gun!)

senses.definition: used to say in a rude and angry way that you are not interested in what somebody has, offers, does, etc.
examples: I got sick of my boss's moaning and told him he could stick the job.

senses.definition: to accept a difficult or unpleasant situation or person
examples: stick something/somebody I don't know how you stick that job.
They’re always arguing—I can’t stick it any longer.
The problem is, my mother can't stick my boyfriend.
stick doing something John can't stick living with his parents.

senses.definition: to become accepted
examples: The police couldn't make the charges stick (= show them to be true).
His friends called him Bart and the name has stuck (= has become the name that everyone calls him).

senses.definition: to say that you will not take any more cards
people remember and believe the bad things they hear about other people, even if they are later shown to be false
to kick somebody very hard, especially when they are on the ground
to attack somebody by criticizing them when they are in a difficult situation
examples: I wonder if the press will put the boot in?

senses.definition: to behave towards somebody in an unfriendly way and try to harm them
to give your opinion, advice, etc. without being asked and when it is probably not wanted
examples: I was getting along very nicely until Patrick stuck his oar in.

senses.definition: to form the shape of a V with the two fingers nearest your thumb and raise your hand in the air with the back part of it facing somebody, done to be rude to them or to show them that you are angry
examples: She enjoys sticking two fingers up to convention.

senses.definition: to be very easy to notice in an unpleasant way
examples: The blue building stood out like a sore thumb among the whitewashed villas.
If you wear a suit to the party, you’ll stand out like a sore thumb.

senses.definition: to be very obvious or easy to notice
examples: It stood out a mile that she was lying.

senses.definition: to kick somebody very hard, especially when they are on the ground
to attack somebody by criticizing them when they are in a difficult situation
examples: I wonder if the press will stick the boot in?

senses.definition: to be remembered for a long time
examples: One of his paintings in particular sticks in my mind.

senses.definition: to be difficult or impossible to say
examples: She wanted to say how sorry she was but the words seemed to stick in her throat.

senses.definition: to be difficult or impossible to accept; to make you angry
to do or say something when there is a risk that you may be wrong
examples: I’ll stick my neck out and say that Bill is definitely the best candidate for the job.

senses.definition: to try to become involved in something that should not involve you
examples: He's always sticking his nose into other people's business.

senses.definition: to be very easy to notice in an unpleasant way
examples: The blue building stuck out like a sore thumb among the whitewashed villas.
If you wear a suit to the party, you'll stick out like a sore thumb.

senses.definition: to be very obvious or easy to notice
examples: It stuck out a mile that she was lying.

senses.definition: to refuse to change your mind about something even when other people are trying to persuade you that you are wrong
to make it clear to somebody that you are angry and are rejecting what they are offering you
made of or covered in a substance that sticks to things that touch it
examples: sticky fingers covered in jam
There's a dish of mango with sweet sticky rice.
Stir in the milk to make a soft but not sticky dough.
Her arms were covered in a sticky substance that could only be blood.
It was covered in a really sticky mess.
The paint was still slightly sticky.
The rubber's gone all sticky.
The white paint was still fresh and sticky to the touch.

senses.definition: with glue (= a sticky substance) on one side so that you can stick it to a surface
examples: sticky tape

senses.definition: hot and slightly wet
examples: a sticky, humid afternoon
The air was hot and sticky.

senses.definition: feeling hot and uncomfortable
examples: She felt hot and sticky after six hours on the bus.

senses.definition: difficult or unpleasant
examples: I always seem to get into sticky situations on holiday.
Their relationship is going through a sticky patch and they’ve decided to have counselling.

senses.definition: so interesting and well organized that the people who visit it stay there for a long time
something unpleasant that happens to somebody, for example punishment or a violent death, usually because of their own actions
examples: He'll come to a sticky end one of these days if he carries on like that.

senses.definition: to be likely to steal something
a difficult situation
difficult to bend or move
examples: a sheet of stiff black cardboard
Scrub away any residue with a stiff brush.
The windows were stiff and she couldn't get them open.
My trousers were getting stiff with mud.
She lay stiff and still beside him.
The captain stood as stiff as a board.
The clothes were stiff with dust and grease.
It was an old blanket, frayed and stiff with dirt.
The brown hair was coarse and stiff.

senses.definition: when a person or a part of their body is stiff, their muscles hurt when they move them
examples: I'm really stiff after that bike ride yesterday.
I've got a stiff neck.
I've got a stiff neck from sleeping in a draught.
You'll get stiff if you don't have a hot bath.
My fingers had gone stiff with cold.
My arm's gone all stiff.
I was stiff from kneeling.
He felt stiff all over.

senses.definition: thick; difficult to stir (= move around with a spoon)
examples: Whisk the egg whites until stiff.

senses.definition: more difficult or severe than usual
examples: It was a stiff climb to the top of the hill.
The company faces stiff competition from its rivals.
The new proposals have met with stiff opposition.
She offered stiff resistance to a thief attempting to snatch her bag.
Firms face stiff penalties for breaking the rules.
a stiff breeze/wind (= one that blows strongly)
The course represents a stiff test of a golfer's skills.
in the face of some very stiff competition
Their punishment seemed rather stiff.
There are stiff fines for illegal dumping.

senses.definition: not friendly or relaxed
examples: The speech he made to welcome them was stiff and formal.
His manner seemed rather stiff and impersonal.
She was aware that her words sounded stiff.
He had the accent and the stiff manner of a school house master.

senses.definition: costing a lot or too much
examples: There's a stiff $30 entrance fee to the exhibition.

senses.definition: strong; containing a lot of alcohol
examples: a stiff whisky
‘What you need is a stiff drink,’ he told her.

senses.definition: to keep calm and hide your feelings when you are in pain or in a difficult situation
examples: He was taught to keep a stiff upper lip and never to cry in public.
Their reaction contrasts sharply with the stiff upper lip of the English.

senses.definition: not moving; calm and quiet
examples: A fallen tree floated in the still water.
Keep still while I brush your hair.
The kids found it hard to stay still.
Can't you sit still?
We stayed in a village where time has stood still (= life has not changed for many years).
Hold still a minute while I pin your dress up.
I held the cat still while the vet gave the injection.
Please sit still!
Suddenly everything went still.
Hold the ladder still while I try to get over the wall.
I wish you'd keep still.
Keep your head still.
Stand still when I'm talking to you!
Stay absolutely still.
The cat remained perfectly still.
The surface of the lake was calm and still.

senses.definition: a still photograph or image does not move, in contrast to a moving image from a film or video
examples: At this time cinema began to influence both still photography and painting.

senses.definition: with no wind
examples: a still summer’s day
the still night air
It was a completely still, warm evening.
The air was strangely still and silent.
Her voice carried on the still air.
It was a still night and the tall trees stood silently against the stars.

senses.definition: not containing bubbles of gas; not fizzy
examples: still mineral water

senses.definition: the voice of God or your conscience, that tells you to do what is morally right
a person who seems to be quiet or shy may surprise you by knowing a lot or having deep feelings
continuing until a particular point in time and not finishing
examples: I am very happy that you all are still alive and well.
Tickets are still available for the 8 o'clock performance.
He's still very young and has a lot to learn.
She still has a chance to win the title.
If you still need help next week, contact me.
I wrote to them last month and I'm still waiting for a reply.
There's still time to change your mind.
I've been playing for 12 years but I still get excited about going to practice.
It's still too early to tell how this will end.
Do you still live at the same address?
It was, and still is, my favourite movie.
Mum, I'm still hungry!

senses.definition: despite what has just been said
examples: Although he promised faithfully to come, I still didn't think he would.
We searched everywhere but we still couldn't find it.
The weather was cold and wet. Still, we had a great time.
I know it's not rational, but I still feel terribly guilty.
He was wounded but he was still able to paint.

senses.definition: used for making a comparison stronger
examples: The next day was warmer still.
If you can manage to get two tickets that's better still.

senses.definition: even more
examples: There was still more bad news to come.

senses.definition: used to say that it is too soon to be sure how a situation will develop
examples: It's still early days. We don't know if the play will be a success.

senses.definition: and certainly not
examples: No explanation was offered, still less an apology.
He’s too shy to ask a stranger the time, much less speak to a room full of people.

senses.definition: a supply of goods that is available for sale in a shop
examples: We have a fast turnover of stock.
in stock That particular model is not currently in stock.
out of stock I'm afraid we're temporarily out of stock.
stock of something We don't carry a large stock of pine furniture.
It is important to carry out regular stock checks.
Do you have futon beds in stock or will I have to order one?
Red tights are out of stock.
The offer is only available while stocks last.
We can supply the table from stock.
They're selling off their old stock cheap.
They're getting rid of their old stock.
The big supermarkets carry huge stocks of most goods.

senses.definition: a supply of something that is available for use
examples: Food stocks are running low.
declining fish stocks in the oceans
a country’s housing stock (= all the houses available for living in)
stock of something She's built up a good stock of teaching materials over the years.
laws to protect fish stocks
dwindling fish stocks in the North Sea
Stocks of coal are running dangerously low.
The housing stock is no longer large enough for the population.

senses.definition: the value of the shares in a company that have been sold
examples: The company's stock hit an all-time high of $94.66.

senses.definition: a share that somebody has bought in a company or business
examples: stock prices
to buy/sell/trade stocks
(British English) to invest in stocks and shares
(North American English) to invest in stocks and bonds
The stocks were valued at $100 000.
The total value of the stocks was over $3 million.
She has about $30 000 in stocks.

senses.definition: money that is lent to a government at a fixed rate of interest; an official document that gives details of this
examples: government stock

senses.definition: farm animals, such as cows and sheep, that are kept for their meat, wool, etc.
examples: breeding stock

senses.definition: having the type of family or ancestors mentioned
a liquid made by cooking bones, meat, etc. in water, used for making soups and sauces
examples: vegetable stock
You can flavour the stock with bay leaves.
Poach the fish in the stock.

senses.definition: a wooden structure with holes for the feet, used in the past to lock criminals in as a form of punishment, especially in a public place
the degree to which somebody is respected or liked by other people
examples: Their stock is high/low.

senses.definition: the part of a gun that you hold against your shoulder when firing it
a garden plant with brightly coloured flowers with a sweet smell
a theatre company that does several different plays in a season; a repertory company
including everything
examples: He sold the business lock, stock and barrel.

senses.definition: in the process of being made, built or prepared
examples: Our new model is already on the stocks and will be available in the spring.

senses.definition: to have a particular amount of belief in something
examples: She no longer puts much stock in their claims.

senses.definition: to stop and think carefully about the way in which a particular situation is developing in order to decide what to do next
examples: It was time to stand back and take stock of his career.

senses.definition: the organ inside the body where food goes when you eat it
examples: stomach pains/cramps
an upset stomach
(British English also) a stomach upset
It's not a good idea to drink (= alcohol) on an empty stomach (= without having eaten anything).
You shouldn't exercise on a full stomach.
A feeling of nausea settled in her stomach.
He had a hangover, so he ordered a sandwich to settle his stomach.
He had a stomach upset.
He violently emptied the contents of his stomach.
Human remains were found among the stomach contents of the shark.
I would get knots in my stomach because I was so scared.
It makes me sick to my stomach to hear such stupid attitudes.
My stomach lurched as another big wave hit the boat.
She's been off work with an upset stomach.
The drug can cause mild stomach upset.
The pains in his stomach were becoming worse.
You shouldn't go to school on an empty stomach.
enzymes in the stomach
the sound of my rumbling stomach

senses.definition: the front part of the body below the chest
examples: The attacker kicked him in the stomach.
Lie on your stomach with your arms by your side.
They crawled along the ground on their stomachs.
exercises to strengthen the stomach muscles
‘I'm eating for two now!’ she said, patting her stomach.
He sucked in his stomach as he walked along the beach.
He was stabbed in the stomach during a street brawl.
I lay on my stomach on the beach.
He had a flat stomach and a muscular chest.

senses.definition: used to say that somebody has been greedy by taking more food than they can eat
to have a nervous feeling in your stomach before doing something
examples: I had butterflies in my stomach as I went to get my exam results.

senses.definition: to not want to eat something
examples: She had no stomach for the leftover stew.

senses.definition: to not have the desire or courage to do something
examples: They had no stomach for a fight.

senses.definition: to be able to see or do unpleasant things without feeling sick or upset
examples: You need a strong stomach to go on the giant roller coaster.

senses.definition: the bottom of the stomach where people say they feel strong feelings, especially fear
examples: He had a sudden sinking feeling in the pit of his stomach.
I felt a sickening feeling in the pit of my stomach when I saw the ambulance.

senses.definition: to remove the contents of somebody’s stomach using a pump, because they have swallowed something harmful
examples: He had his stomach pumped after taking an overdose.

senses.definition: feeling very angry or worried
examples: Nora turned sick to her stomach on hearing this news.
It makes me sick to my stomach to hear such stupid attitudes.

senses.definition: feeling that you want to vomit
to make you feel upset, sick or full of horror
examples: Pictures of the burnt corpses turned my stomach.
The smell of the dead dog turned his stomach.

senses.definition: a hard solid mineral substance that is found in the ground, often used for building
examples: Most of the houses are built of stone.
stone walls
a stone floor/bridge/carving/pillar/slab
a brick and stone building
a flight of stone steps
a huge block of stone
He is a sculptor who works mainly in stone.
The path's stone flags were worn and broken.
The stone is cut into blocks ready for building.
The walls were hewn from local stone.
a carved stone fireplace
names carved in stone
The walls were made of stone.

senses.definition: a small piece of rock of any shape
examples: a pile of stones
Some children were throwing stones into the lake.
Some loose stones tumbled down the slope behind her.
The boys were caught throwing stones at passing trains.
The boat broke in two and sank like a stone.
(figurative) The temperature dropped like a stone.
A group of children pelted firefighters with stones.

senses.definition: a piece of stone shaped for a particular purpose
examples: These words are carved on the stone beside his grave.

senses.definition: a rare valuable stone, such as a diamond, that is used in jewellery
examples: She had the stone set in a ring.

senses.definition: a hard shell containing the nut or seed in the middle of some types of fruit
examples: cherry/peach stones

senses.definition: a small piece of hard material that can form in the bladder or kidney and cause pain
examples: kidney stones

senses.definition: (in the UK) a unit for measuring weight, equal to 6.35 kilograms or 14 pounds
examples: He weighs over 15 stone.
She's trying to lose a stone.

senses.definition: unable to be changed
examples: People should remember that our proposals aren't set in stone.
These rules are not set in stone.

senses.definition: to be a person who does not show other people sympathy
to achieve two things at the same time with one action
to try every possible course of action in order to find or achieve something
almost impossible to obtain
examples: Getting an apology from him was like getting blood from a stone.

senses.definition: you should not criticize other people, because they will easily find ways of criticizing you
a person who moves from place to place, job to job, etc. does not have a lot of money, possessions or friends but is free from responsibilities
a very short distance away
examples: We live just a stone's throw from here.
The hotel is within a stone's throw of the beach.

senses.definition: a place where a bus or train stops regularly for passengers to get on or off
examples: I get off at the next stop.
Is this your stop?
Winchester will be the next station stop.
(North American English) Where's the nearest subway stop?
Piccadilly Circus is the next stop.
It's only a few stops on the subway.
I'm getting off at the last stop.
You're not allowed to get off between stops.
We were chatting and missed our stop.
The restaurant is only a few subway stops away.
The music shop was just three tram stops away from his flat.

senses.definition: an act of stopping or stopping something; the state of being stopped
examples: The trip included an overnight stop in Brussels.
We made several stops along the way.
She brought the car to a stop.
Work has temporarily come to a stop while the funding is reviewed.
It is time to put a stop to the violence.
They campaigned to put up a stop sign at the busy intersection outside the school.
Between twelve and two, everything comes to a dead stop.
He is making a campaign stop in Lubbock, Texas.
She brought the car to an abrupt stop.
The police found the drugs during a routine traffic stop.
The truck came to a sudden stop.
There will be a stop at Aboyne.
We had a lunch stop at Timperley.
a stop for refreshments
to put a stop to all the arguments
The flight took 15 hours including the refuelling stop.
The President made an unscheduled stop in Quebec on Monday.
After a brief stop, the bus set off again.
New York is the final stop on the band's international tour.
Please keep your seatbelts fastened until we've come to a complete stop.
They made a quick stop at a small roadside diner for supper.

senses.definition: the mark ( . ) used at the end of a sentence and in some abbreviations, for example e.g.
a row of pipes on an organ that produce the different sounds
a handle on an organ that the player pushes in or pulls out to control the sound produced by the pipes
a speech sound made by stopping the flow of air coming out of the mouth and then suddenly releasing it, for example /p/, /k/, /t/
to stop completely
examples: The car began to shudder and eventually came to a full stop in front of the church.

senses.definition: frequently starting and stopping again; not continuously
examples: Babies do not grow at a steady rate but in stops and starts.

senses.definition: to make the greatest effort possible to achieve something
to no longer move; to make somebody/something no longer move
examples: The car stopped at the traffic lights.
Ann stopped in front of the house.
This train doesn’t stop at Oxford.
stop somebody/something He was stopped by the police for speeding.
She stopped the car opposite the school.
Suddenly he stopped dead: what was he doing?
The buses stop outside the school.
Soldiers took up positions along roads, stopping and searching cars.
Passers-by stopped and stared in the window.
She made them stop the car and let her out.
Flooding has stopped the traffic through the center of town.

senses.definition: to no longer continue to do something; to make somebody/something no longer do something
examples: Can't you just stop?
stop doing something That phone never stops ringing!
Don't you ever stop talking?
Please stop crying and tell me what's wrong.
She criticizes everyone and the trouble is, she doesn't know when to stop.
stop somebody/something Stop me (= make me stop talking) if I'm boring you.
Stop it! You're hurting me.
stop what… Mike immediately stopped what he was doing.
Sorry to interrupt, but I have to disagree with that.
Could I just say something here?
If I could, let me stop you there for a moment and go back to your previous point.
Actually, we seem to have strayed a bit from the topic. Can we go back to the first point?
Just a moment, Sue. Can we hear what Jack has to say on this?
May I interrupt you there? I don't think that's true.
I’m sorry, but we’re running short on time. Can you please summarize very quickly so we can finish up?
I appreciate your enthusiasm on this topic, but I’m afraid we have a couple more people to hear from.
Could you two please discuss that issue privately after the meeting? We have several more items to cover and need to move on at this point.
I’m sorry, I really have to stop you there. We've run out of time.
Let’s save that conversation for another time.
He never knows when to stop.
He couldn't stop thinking about her.
I was enjoying myself so much I didn't want to stop.
We need to stop making excuses.
After three weeks we had stopped expecting to hear any news.
She's trying to stop smoking and lose weight.
They can't stop talking about the holiday.
She didn't stop working until she was 80.
They paid farmers to stop using chemicals.
It's time to stop playing and go home.

senses.definition: to end or finish; to make something end or finish
examples: When is this fighting going to stop?
The bus service stops at midnight.
stop doing something Has it stopped raining yet?
stop something Doctors couldn't stop the bleeding.
The referee was forced to stop the game because of heavy snow.
She called on both sides to stop the violence.
When is the violence going to stop?
The sobs came less frequently, then stopped altogether.
The story stops and starts, with little emphasis on continuity.
The peace movement failed to stop the war.
He knew he had to stop the blood flow.
On the farm, the work never stops.

senses.definition: to prevent somebody from doing something; to prevent something from happening
examples: stop somebody/something I want to go and you can't stop me.
efforts to stop the spread of the disease
There's no stopping us now (= nothing can prevent us from achieving what we want to achieve).
stop somebody/something (from) doing something You can't stop people (from) saying what they think.
They tried to stop me from leaving.
There's nothing to stop you from accepting the offer.
He's dangerous and needs to be stopped.
Measures must be taken to stop the spread of the virus.
The activists failed to stop the tests from going ahead.
If she wants to go, I'm certainly not going to try and stop her.
Technology could help to stop future attacks.
The internet has stopped young people from talking to each other.

senses.definition: to end an activity for a short time in order to do something
examples: stop for something I'm hungry. Let's stop for lunch.
We stopped for the night in Port Augusta.
stop to do something We stopped to admire the scenery.
People just don't stop to think about the consequences.
The film really makes you stop and think.
If you just stop and listen, it's amazing what you can hear.

senses.definition: to no longer be working or functioning; to make something be no longer working or functioning
examples: Why has the engine stopped?
What time is it? My watch has stopped.
I felt as if my heart had stopped.
stop something Can you stop the printer once it’s started?

senses.definition: to stay somewhere for a short time, especially at somebody’s house
examples: I'm not stopping. I just came to give you this message.
stop for something Can you stop for tea?

senses.definition: to prevent money from being paid
examples: stop something to stop a cheque (= tell the bank not to pay it)
Employees of the failed company will have their wages stopped from tomorrow.
stop something from something (British English) Dad threatened to stop £1 a week from our pocket money if we didn't clean our rooms.

senses.definition: to block, fill or close a hole, an opening, etc.
examples: Stop up the other end of the tube, will you?
I stopped my ears but still heard her cry out.

senses.definition: to be willing to do anything to get what you want, even if it is dishonest or wrong
examples: She’ll stop at nothing to make money.

senses.definition: to stop measuring time in a game or an activity that has a time limit
to suddenly make somebody stop by frightening or surprising them; to suddenly stop because something has frightened or surprised you
examples: The question stopped Alice in her tracks.
Suddenly he stopped dead in his tracks: what was he doing?
(figurative) The disease was stopped in its tracks by immunization programmes.

senses.definition: to suddenly stop, or make somebody suddenly stop, doing something
examples: He stopped short when he heard his name.
‘I’m pregnant,’ she said. That stopped him short.

senses.definition: to be unwilling to do something because it may involve a risk, but to nearly do it
examples: She stopped short of calling the president a liar.
The protest stopped short of a violent confrontation.

senses.definition: a large shop that sells many different types of goods
examples: It's available at London's three biggest stores.

senses.definition: a shop, large or small
examples: I'm going to the store.
His father opened a small grocery store.
Retail stores across Europe were reporting no stock left of the game.
You should be able to get it in any good health food store.
He looked around for a liquor store.
Buying store brands certainly works out cheaper.
Ralph Lauren's flagship store on Madison Avenue
The game will hit stores in January.
The company operates four stores in Maryland.
The company plans to open two new stores in Dublin.
The new book has been flying off store shelves.
The store offers a comprehensive line of auto parts.
You can buy music from an online store.
Ask at your local hardware store.
The chain has endured another terrible month at its high-street stores.
You can park on the street right outside the store.

senses.definition: a website that sells things
examples: an online store
You can get it on the app store.

senses.definition: a quantity or supply of something that you have and use
examples: her secret store of chocolate
a vast store of knowledge
your body's fat stores
Stores of blood sugar are metabolized to produce energy.
This is vital information to add to your store of knowledge.

senses.definition: goods of a particular kind or for a particular purpose
examples: medical stores
They had trouble keeping rats out of the food stores.

senses.definition: a place where goods of a particular kind are kept
examples: The grain store holds several thousand tonnes.
The soldiers were charged with guarding the weapons stores.
The mill ceased operations in 1940 and was used as a grain store.
You'll find a ladder in the equipment store.
We're using the shed as a temporary store for all our stuff.

senses.definition: waiting to happen to somebody
examples: We don't know what life holds in store for us.
If she had known what lay in store for her, she would never have agreed to go.

examples: My grandmother is 90 and still going strong.

senses.definition: to be able to see or do unpleasant things without feeling sick or upset
examples: You need a strong stomach to go on the giant roller coaster.

senses.definition: in a way that shows definite and serious opinions or beliefs

senses.definition: to a great degree or extent
examples: Health spending is strongly linked to the country's wealth.

senses.definition: in a way that is easy to notice
examples: The room smelt strongly of polish.

senses.definition: with a lot of power or force
examples: a light shining strongly

senses.definition: in a way that means something cannot be easily broken or damaged

senses.definition: the way in which the parts of something are connected together, arranged or organized; a particular arrangement of parts

senses.definition: a hard fight in which people try to obtain or achieve something, especially something that somebody else does not want them to have

the campaign for parliamentary reform
an advertising campaign

the struggle for independence
the struggle between good and evil

a drive to reduce energy consumption
the war against crime

the daily struggle for survival

the struggle against fascism

senses.definition: a physical fight between two people or groups of people, especially when one of them is trying to escape, or to get something from the other
examples: There were no signs of a struggle at the murder scene.

struggle with somebody He was involved in a struggle with the police.

There were no signs of a struggle at the murder scene.

senses.definition: to move somewhere or do something with difficulty

senses.definition: to compete or argue with somebody/something, especially in order to get something

senses.definition: used to say that something is stupid or not true

senses.definition: all of something, especially when you think that it is not very much

senses.definition: used to introduce a short statement of the main points of a discussion, speech, etc.

senses.definition: to give a summary of something
examples: This essay briefly summarizes some of our approaches.

The available evidence clearly leads to the conclusion that the media do have an influence on the public perception of crime.
The main conclusion to be drawn from this study is that public perception of crime is significantly influenced by crime news reporting.
This study has shown that people’s fear of crime is out of all proportion to crime itself.
Fear of crime is out of all proportion to the actual level of crime, and the reasons for this can be summarized as follows. First…
Overall/In general, women are more likely than men to feel insecure walking alone after dark.
The findings are summarized in Table 4.
The main findings of this research are summarized below.
The research has been usefully summarized in an article by Greenwood.
The argument can be summarized as follows:…

senses.definition: a short statement that gives only the main points of something, not the details

summary of something The following is a summary of our conclusions.

senses.definition: you must not take too seriously a small sign that something is happening or will happen in the future, because the situation could change
the star that shines in the sky during the day and gives the earth heat and light
examples: The sun was shining and birds were singing.
the sun’s rays

the rising/setting sun

senses.definition: the light and heat from the sun

wrinkles caused by sun damage

senses.definition: any star around which planets move
to make good use of opportunities, good conditions, etc. while they last
a position in which you are comfortable or have an advantage over other people
used to emphasize that you are talking about a very large number of things
examples: We talked about everything under the sun.
I’ve been called all the names under the sun!

senses.definition: when the sun rises or sets

senses.definition: the day of the week after Saturday and before Monday, thought of as either the first or the last day of the week
examples: It's Sunday today, isn't it?

senses.definition: a newspaper published on a Sunday

examples: You won't find it, not in a month of Sundays.

senses.definition: a large shop that sells food, drinks and goods used in the home. People choose what they want from the shelves and pay for it as they leave.

senses.definition: to like a particular sports team, watch their games, etc.

senses.definition: to provide everything necessary, especially money, so that somebody/something can live or exist

senses.definition: to help to show that something is true
examples: Current data support this hypothesis.

not exactly/entirely/absolutely/really sure

senses.definition: certain to do something or to happen

She’s sure to be picked for the team.

senses.definition: that can be trusted or relied on
examples: It's a sure sign of economic recovery.

It’s certain that they will agree.
They are certain to agree.
She’s sure to be picked for the team.
It’s sure to rain.
Is it definite that he’s leaving?
That kind of behaviour is guaranteed to make him angry.

senses.definition: steady and confident
examples: We admired her sure touch at the keyboard.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody to do something

senses.definition: something that is likely to happen, to succeed or to be suitable

senses.definition: used to say ‘yes’ to somebody or to agree to something

senses.definition: the flat upper part of a piece of furniture, that is used for working on
examples: She's cleaned all the kitchen surfaces.

senses.definition: the outer appearance of a person, thing or situation; the qualities that you see or notice, that are not hidden

senses.definition: when not thought about deeply or carefully and completely; when not looked at carefully
examples: It seems like a good idea on the surface but there are sure to be problems.

senses.definition: to deal with, understand, or find out about only a small part of a subject or problem
examples: We left feeling that we had just scratched the surface of this fascinating country.

senses.definition: medical treatment of injuries or diseases that involves cutting open a person’s body and often removing or replacing some parts; the branch of medicine connected with this treatment
examples: major/minor surgery
to undergo heart/knee/shoulder surgery

The doctor had to perform emergency surgery to the patient's head.
She's a specialist in reconstructive and cosmetic surgery.

patients recovering from hip replacement surgery
He will need heart bypass surgery.
My brother went on to study surgery.

senses.definition: a place where a doctor, dentist or vet sees patients
examples: a doctor’s/dentist’s/vet's surgery

senses.definition: the time during which a doctor, dentist or vet is available to see patients
examples: morning/afternoon/evening surgery
surgery hours

senses.definition: a time when people can meet their Member of Parliament to ask questions and get help
examples: a constituency surgery

senses.definition: an event, a piece of news, etc. that is unexpected or that happens suddenly
examples: What a nice surprise!

a surprise attack

Your mother's in for a bit of a surprise when she gets home.

senses.definition: a feeling caused by something happening suddenly or unexpectedly
examples: a look of surprise
in surprise She looked up in surprise.
surprise at something He gasped with surprise at her strength.
surprise at seeing, hearing, etc. They couldn't conceal their surprise at seeing us together.
I got a surprise when I saw the bill.
to somebody's surprise To everyone's surprise, the plan succeeded.
Much to my surprise, I passed.

When we went inside we got a nasty surprise.

She showed no surprise at the news.

senses.definition: the use of methods that cause feelings of surprise
examples: A successful campaign should have an element of surprise.

senses.definition: used to show that something is not a surprise to you, as you could easily have predicted that it would happen or be true
examples: One of the candidates was the manager's niece, and surprise, surprise, she got the job.
Bob turned up half an hour late, surprise surprise.

senses.definition: used when giving somebody a surprise
examples: Surprise, surprise! Look who's here!

senses.definition: to happen unexpectedly so that somebody is slightly shocked; to surprise somebody
examples: His frankness took her by surprise.
The storm took us completely by surprise.

senses.definition: to attack or capture somebody/something unexpectedly or without warning
examples: The police took the burglars by surprise.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel surprised
examples: surprise somebody It wouldn't surprise me if they got married soon.
surprise somebody how, what It's always surprised me how popular he is.
it surprises somebody that… It surprises me that you've never sung professionally.

it surprises somebody to do something Would it surprise you to know that I'm thinking of leaving?
The outcome didn’t surprise me at all.
Sorry, I didn’t mean to startle you.

We were rather taken aback by her hostile reaction.
His arrogance astounded her.
The outcome did not surprise me at all.
They wanted to surprise their mother and get the breakfast ready.

senses.definition: to attack, discover, etc., somebody suddenly and unexpectedly
examples: The army attacked at night to surprise the rebels.

senses.definition: feeling or showing surprise
examples: a surprised look

surprised at/by somebody/something I was surprised at how quickly she agreed.
I'm surprised at you, behaving like that in front of the kids.
surprised to see, hear, learn, discover, find They were surprised to find that he'd already left.
surprised (that)… You shouldn’t be surprised (that) he didn’t come.

to be a little/a bit/quite surprised

senses.definition: causing surprise
examples: It’s not surprising (that) they lost.

For a big man, he could move with surprising speed.

examples: surround something/somebody Tall trees surround the lake.

senses.definition: an investigation of the opinions, behaviour, etc. of a particular group of people, which is usually done by asking them questions
examples: A recent survey showed 75 per cent of those questioned were in favour of the plan.

senses.definition: to measure and record the features of an area of land, for example in order to make a map or in preparation for building

senses.definition: to have an idea that something is probably true or likely to happen, especially something bad, but without having definite proof

suspect somebody/something Whom do the police suspect?

swear (that)… I solemnly swear (that) it will never happen again.

swear to do something She made him swear not to tell anyone.

senses.definition: to promise that you are telling the truth

a piece of clothing for the upper part of the body, made of wool or cotton, with long sleeves

a grey merino wool turtleneck sweater

senses.definition: to move over an area, especially in order to look for something

senses.definition: to win all the prizes, etc. in a competition
to make somebody fall suddenly and deeply in love with you

senses.definition: to win an election by a large number of votes; to make somebody win an election with a large number of votes

senses.definition: containing, or tasting as if it contains, a lot of sugar

an overpowering, sickly sweet smell

senses.definition: having a pleasant sound

senses.definition: pleasant and not containing any harmful substances
examples: the sweet air of a mountain village

senses.definition: making you feel happy and/or satisfied
examples: Goodnight. Sweet dreams.

senses.definition: attractive

senses.definition: having or showing a kind character
examples: She gave him her sweetest smile.

senses.definition: used to show that you approve of something

senses.definition: to like somebody very much in a romantic way
to like food that contains a lot of sugar
used to say how pleasant your home is (especially when you really mean that it is not pleasant at all)
how and when you want to, even though this might annoy other people
examples: He always does the work, but in his own sweet time.

senses.definition: to say or do pleasant things in order to keep somebody in a good mood so that they will agree to do something for you

senses.definition: what is important is what people or things are, not what they are called
everything is all right
pleasant but not lasting a long time

senses.definition: nothing at all. People say ‘sweet FA’ to avoid saying ‘fuck all’.
romantic words
examples: to whisper sweet nothings in somebody’s ear

senses.definition: the pleasant feeling of being successful
a small piece of sweet food, usually made with sugar and/or chocolate and eaten between meals
examples: a packet of sweets
a sweet shop

Add some honey to make it sweet.
Suck this sweet—it might soothe your throat.

senses.definition: a sweet dish eaten at the end of a meal
examples: I haven't made a sweet today.

senses.definition: a way of addressing somebody that you like or love

senses.definition: a period of time during which you swim

a sponsored swim

senses.definition: (in compounds) related to or used for swimming

senses.definition: to move through water by moving your arms and legs, without touching the bottom

senses.definition: to spend time swimming for pleasure

senses.definition: to move through or across water
examples: Sharks must swim or die.
swim + adv./prep. A shoal of fish swam past.

senses.definition: to be covered with a lot of liquid
examples: swim (in something) The main course was swimming in oil.

senses.definition: a small device that you press or move up and down in order to turn a light or piece of electrical equipment on and off
examples: a light switch

to flick/press a switch
to throw a switch (= to move a large switch)

senses.definition: a change from one thing to another, especially when this is sudden and complete

senses.definition: the points on a railway line
a thin stick that bends easily
not paying enough attention to what you need to do

senses.definition: to change or make something change from one thing to another

switch something over Your broadband will be switched over in less than a week.
switch something He switched sides halfway through the debate.

senses.definition: to do somebody else’s job for a short time or work during different hours so that they can do your job or work during your usual hours
examples: switch (with somebody) I can't work next weekend—will you switch with me?
switch something (with somebody) Have you been able to switch your shift with anyone?
switch (something) (over/around/round) Can we switch our shifts around?

senses.definition: a person, an object, an event, etc. that represents a more general quality or situation
examples: The vase is decorated with religious symbols.
symbol of something The new school stands as a symbol of hope for a better future.
Mandela became a symbol of the anti-apartheid struggle.
The drummer hit the cymbal one last time.
The owl is a well-recognized symbol of wisdom.
Headaches may be a sign of stress.
They gave no indication as to how the work should be done.
Symptoms include a sore throat.
The rise in inflation was just one symptom of the poor state of the economy.
The dove is a universal symbol of peace.
the economic indicators
Chest pains can be a warning signal of heart problems.
White has always been a symbol of purity in Western cultures.
Eggs are seen as the symbol of new life.
Guevara has come to represent a powerful symbol of defiance.
The Berlin wall was the supreme symbol of the Cold War.
The company car is an outward symbol of the employee's status.
The dove is a universal symbol of peace.
The villagers took fertility symbols into the fields to ensure a good harvest.
a symbol of royal power

senses.definition: a sign, number, letter, etc. that has a fixed meaning, especially in science, mathematics and music
examples: the mathematical symbol for infinity
Hotels that display this symbol offer activities for children.
What is the chemical symbol for copper?
A list of symbols used on the map is given in the index.
A list of phonetic symbols is given in the front of the dictionary.
All GM products carry an identifying symbol.
Always look out for the special ABTA symbol at your travel agent's.
The bottle had a skull and crossbones symbol on it.
The coin bears a Jewish symbol.
What does this little symbol mean?
You can use your tokens wherever you see this symbol.
a message written in symbols

senses.definition: the feeling of being sorry for somebody; showing that you understand and care about somebody’s problems
examples: sympathy for somebody to express/feel sympathy for somebody
I have no sympathy for Jan—it's all her own fault.
I wish he'd show me a little more sympathy.
Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to the victims of the war.
out of sympathy for somebody Shops were closed out of sympathy for the victims.
(formal) May we offer our deepest sympathies on the death of your wife.
(formal) I would like to extend our sincere sympathies to his family at this sad time.
I'm sorry you're not well. I hope you feel better soon.
I am sorry to hear that.
That's bad luck.
How awful for you.
I'm sorry for your loss
He didn't get much sympathy from anyone.
I don't want your sympathy!
I felt a pang of sympathy for her.
It's hard to find any sympathy for such an evil man.
She expressed her deepest sympathy for him.
She married him more out of sympathy than love.
She says I haven't given her enough sympathy.
She seemed to feel some sympathy for the patients.
Their plight aroused considerable public sympathy.
a total lack of human sympathy
My sympathy lies with his wife.

senses.definition: the act of showing support for or approval of an idea, a cause, an organization, etc.
examples: in sympathy with somebody/something The seamen went on strike in sympathy with (= to show their support for) the dockers.
Her sympathies lie with the anti-abortion lobby.
The government showed sympathy to their cause.
She had every sympathy with him.

senses.definition: friendship and understanding between people who have similar opinions or interests
examples: There was no personal sympathy between them.
He has a total lack of sympathy for young people.

senses.definition: happening because something else has happened
examples: Share prices slipped in sympathy with the German market.

senses.definition: not agreeing with or not wanting to support somebody/something
a change in your body or mind that shows that you are not healthy
examples: Symptoms include a headache and sore throat.
If symptoms persist, consult your doctor.
symptom of something to experience symptoms of anxiety and depression
to show/develop symptoms of illness
to relieve/alleviate symptoms
She was hospitalized with extreme flu-like symptoms.
40% of patients were treated within three hours of the onset of symptoms.
Can you describe your symptoms?
Cigarettes can aggravate the symptoms of a cold.
Not all carriers of the disease develop symptoms.
Nurses are taught how to identify and treat the symptoms of poisoning.
She had all the classic symptoms of the disorder.
The patient was admitted presenting with flu symptoms.
These virus infections display obvious visual symptoms.
after two symptom-free years
the physical symptoms that are the result of stress
Look out for symptoms of depression.

senses.definition: a sign that something exists, especially something bad
examples: The rise in inflation was just one symptom of the poor state of the economy.
Their relationship was obviously failing, but they just ignored the symptoms.
Headaches may be a sign of stress.
They gave no indication as to how the work should be done.
Symptoms include a sore throat.
The rise in inflation was just one symptom of the poor state of the economy.
The dove is a universal symbol of peace.
the economic indicators
Chest pains can be a warning signal of heart problems.

senses.definition: an organized set of ideas or theories or a particular way of doing something
examples: reform of the country's education system
the criminal justice system
the healthcare system
the legal/financial/political system
system for doing something Systems are in place for dealing with complaints.
system of something a system of government
How is the system organized?
The game has a complex scoring system.
Under the new system, all children will be monitored by a senior social worker.
This system allows you to study at your own speed.
Fortunately the class system is not as rigid as it once was.
The law applies to schools within the state system.
The country's economic system is close to collapse.
The governor referred to a prison system that was bankrupt of compassion.
They have a modern and efficient healthcare system.
They introduced a democratic parliamentary system in the 1980s.
He played the legal system to his own advantage.
the need to modernize the judicial system
The justice system is based on just one or two fundamental principles.
a backlog of cases clogging up the system
Once your systems are in place you can concentrate on the main focus of your business.
The new system is designed to eliminate fraud.
We need to re-examine the systems we are currently using.
The so-called reforms merely perpetuate an unjust system.
They devised an appropriate system for presenting the required information.
There is a national system for exchanging essential information.
We are implementing a new system of stock control.
Our system of granting visas is unnecessarily complicated.

senses.definition: a group of things, pieces of equipment, etc. that are connected or work together
examples: They installed a security system but it failed.
How does the system work?
The alarm system had been switched off.
He is currently on a life-support system in the local hospital.
attempts to disrupt the rail system
a fault in the sound system
The air-conditioning system failed.
For this month only, installing the system is free.

senses.definition: a set of computer equipment and programs that are used together
examples: to develop a new computer system
We're designing a voice-recognition system.
computerized information systems
The latest computer system is much more efficient.
an information retrieval system
The system runs on this workstation.
Just reboot the system and try again.

senses.definition: a human or an animal body, or a part of it, when it is being thought of as the organs and processes that make it function
examples: Wait until the drugs have passed through your system.
the male reproductive system
Returning to work after a long break can be a terrible shock to the system (= a big change that is difficult to deal with).

senses.definition: the rules or people that control a country or an organization, especially when they seem to be unfair because you cannot change them
examples: You can't beat the system (= you must accept it).
You have to learn how to work the system if you want to succeed.
young people rebelling against the system
It's not your fault—blame the system.
She spent her years at school fighting the system.
They are all part of the corrupt system we need to change.

senses.definition: used to say that everything is working well or that everything is ready for something to happen or be successful
examples: The firm struggled to generate much business at the start, but now it's all systems go.
Last weekend's heavy snowfall means it's all systems go for the ski season.

senses.definition: to do something so that you no longer feel a very strong emotion or have a strong desire
examples: I was very angry with him, but now I feel I've got it out of my system.
